college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructor: 
dr. Meike Morren (VU) and prof. dr. Bas Donkers (EUR)


Course Description:
Natural Language Processing (NLP) comprises statistical and machine learning tools for automatically analysing text data to derive useful insights from it. Vast amounts of information are stored in this form, and hence NLP has become one of the essential technologies of the big data age. In this course, core concepts and techniques from the area will be studied, with a focus on methods that are popular in business applications. These include n-gram and word vector coding, sentiment analysis, word embeddings and topic modelling.

This course offers students a theoretically informed understanding of NLP. It aims at broadening the knowledge of the methods involved in NLP, as well as a hands-on experience with the steps that need to be taken in an NLP project. We focus on three aspects:

a) to create deep(er) understanding of the main methods in NLP (n-gram, lexicon approach, word embeddings and other advanced machine learning methods);
b) to obtain an experience to scrape and clean the data yourself;
c) to apply this knowledge and experience in a group assignment which gives you the possibility to show your creativity.

By the end of this course, you will be able to analyse and evaluate NLP approaches. Moreover, you will apply this knowledge and skills in a real-life setting, enabling you to translate and apply theoretical knowledge into practice.

Topics covered:
1. Information theory, regular expressions and scraping (tokenization, stemming, lemmatization, parsing).
2. Word vectors and dimension reduction based on bag of words (n-grams)
3. Sentiment analysis (lexicon-based vs model-based)
4. Topic models (LDA)
5. Word embeddings (Word2Vec, GloVe, BERT)
Leerdoelen By the end of the course students will be able to:

Knowledge and Understanding:  Demonstrate knowledge of Natural Language Processing, from data cleaning to advanced machine learning approaches, including: Information theory, regular expressions, scraping and data cleaning (tokenization, stemming, lemmatization, parsing); word vectors and dimension reduction based on bag of words (n-grams, PCA); sentiment analysis (lexicon-based vs model-based); topic models (LDA); word embeddings (Word2Vec, GloVe, BERT)

Application of Knowledge: Apply this theoretical knowledge and experience in group assignments. Analyze and evaluate NLP approaches.

Making judgement: Evaluate the effectiveness of marketing expenditure, evaluate the appropriateness of a model

Communication: Written and oral presentation of results within the research project.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
Language and Training Centre (LTC)
text:
Inhoud

Deze cursus bestaat uit 10 wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 2 uur. Er is geen afsluitende toets maar tijdens de cursus geeft de docent feedback op je spreekvaardigheid.

Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Nederlands Spreekvaardigheid?

Na het behalen van niveau B2 kun je je goed redden in het Nederlands maar om de taal goed en vlot te gebruiken moet je blijven werken aan je spreekvaardigheid en het uitbreiden van je woordenschat. In deze cursus wordt niet of nauwelijks geschreven maar ga je discussiëren over actuele onderwerpen en bespreek je interessante teksten. Elke les leer je een paar  nieuwe uitdrukkingen en of spreekwoorden. Ook oefen je met presenteren in het Nederlands en lees je thuis een Nederlands boek dat in de les met elkaar besproken wordt.

Leerdoelen Het uitbreiden van je woordenschat en de taal vlot leren gebruiken.  Belangrijk om te weten
  • Let op: deze cursus wordt online gegeven via Zoom Wellicht zullen een paar sessies op de campus gegeven kunnen worden, dat is nu nog niet zeker.
  • Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
  • Het (online) cursusmateriaal is bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. 
  • In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
  • Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer twee uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
  • De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 10 en maximaal 14 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 10 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.
  • Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. 
  • Er is geen afsluitend examen maar tijdens de cursus geeft de docent feedback op je spreekvaardigheid.
  • Je ontvangt een bewijs van deelname als je minimaal 80% van lessen aanwezig bent.
  • Lees ook onze voorwaarden.
Data en tijden Maandagen 18.00-20.00
Data: 23 januari - 27 maart 2023
Online via Zoom
Examen in week 14, maandag 3 april 2023
Deadline: 11 januari 2023

course_title: Negentiende eeuw I: Van Kant tot neokantianisme
college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
lecturers: ['dr. B Leeuwenburgh', 'J van der Klaauw, MA', 'prof.dr. HA Krop']
text:
Inhoud Aan het einde van de 18e eeuw ontwikkelt zich in Duitsland stormachtig het Duits idealisme op basis van de problematiek die Kants kritische filosofie deed ontstaan en die hij  in zijn derde kritiek probeerde te entameren. De basis van dit denken is Kant, met name diens teleologie, dat als model dient voor een geschiedfilosofie, die de geschiedenis leest als een proces van menselijke bevrijding en emancipatie. Hegel meende dat na de Franse Revolutie en Kants kriticisme dit proces zowel in politiek als intellectueel opzicht voltooid is met de opbouw van de moderne (rechts)staat en het ontstaan van een christendom dat tot zijn redelijke kern zou zijn herleid. Rond 1830 begint Hegels roem te verbleken. Leerdoelen

De werkcolleges zijn voor voltijdstudenten verplicht.

De colleges worden niet opgenomen.

Overzicht van de ontwikkeling van de negentiende-eeuwse wijsbegeerte te beginnen bij Kant. Na deze cursus is de student in staat het verband te leggen tussen politieke en wetenschappelijke ontwikkelingen aan de ene  en de wijsgerige ontwikkelingen aan de andere kant. Verder heeft de student een praktische vaardigheid opgedaan jet het interpreteren van filosofische teksten uit de 19e eeuw.

course_title: Negentiende eeuw II: Van Kant tot neokantianisme
college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud In de cursus ‘Negentiende Eeuw II’ wordt inhoudelijk voortgebouwd op de ideeënhistorische context, de filosofische stromingen, ontwikkelingen en debatten die in de cursus ‘Negentiende Eeuw I’ zijn geïntroduceerd. Hierbij worden de volgende thema’s in chronologische volgorde en in hun onderlinge samenhang behandeld. 
            Ten eerste de opkomst van het vooruitgangsdenken in Frankrijk, Engeland, Nederland en de Verenigde Staten, waarbij achtereenvolgens aandacht wordt besteed aan de ideeënontwikkeling van de grondlegger van het positivisme, Auguste Comte, de bloei van het utilitarisme in Engeland, zoals in gang gezet door Jeremy Bentham en verder uitgebouwd door John Stuart Mill, de unieke ‘ervaringswijsbegeerte’ van Cornelis Willem Opzoomer en het Amerikaanse pragmatisme van Charles Sanders Peirce en William James.  
            De invloedrijke theorie van natuurlijke selectie van de ‘philosophical naturalist’ Charles Darwin staat in de tweede week centraal, zij het ruim ingebed in het bredere debat over evolutie en de positie van de mens in de natuur, waarbij ook dieper wordt ingegaan op de ideeënontwikkeling van de eerste darwinisten en sociaal-darwinisten.
            In de periode waarin Darwin zijn theorie ontwikkelde (1830 – 1860) worden ook de eerste contouren zichtbaar van een nieuwe filosofische discipline: wetenschapsfilosofie. Hoe zich dat proces voltrok middels baanbrekende publicaties van John Herschel, William Whewell, John Stuart Mill en Ernst Mach vormt het eerste thema. Het tweede thema in deze derde week is geheel gewijd aan het in politiek-maatschappelijk opzicht uiterst invloedrijke historisch materialisme van Karl Marx.
            In de laatste week worden in aansluiting op de behandeling van het neo-kantianisme in de cursus ‘Negentiende Eeuw I’ onder de noemer ‘van pessimisme tot Umwertung’ de filosofieën van twee zeer uitgesproken, karakteristieke denkers uit de negentiende eeuw behandeld, te weten Arthur Schopenhauer en Friedrich Nietzsche.
 

De werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten. 

De colleges worden niet opgenomen.

Leerdoelen

1. Beschrijven van de belangrijkste filosofische stromingen in het Negentiende-Eeuwse Engeland, Frankrijk, Duitsland en Nederland.
2. Uitleggen van de filosofische begrippen die de inhoudelijke filosofische discussie in de negentiende eeuw kenschetsen. Voorbeelden van begrippen zijn onder andere neo - Kantianisme, idealisme, vooruitgangsoptimisme, positivisme, uniformitarianisme, transcendentalisme etc.
3. Leren samenvatten middels het maken van collegedictaat.
4. Het schriftelijk logisch onderbouwen van een eigen filosofische stellingname ter voorbereiding op een werkcollege.
5. Het schriftelijk evalueren van een eerder ingenomen filosofische stellingname (zie 4) ter voorbereiding op een werkcollege.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Course description: 

Being able to negotiate successfully is essential in establishing and maintaining fruitful business relationships and transactions. In this course, we utilize a psychological perspective to develop professional negotiation skills. We will focus on cognitions, emotions and motivations that impact the negotiation process and outcomes, and explore different negotiation strategies and their outcomes in terms of potential value, efficiency and relationship quality. We will also address some basic knowledge about individual decision making. This course is very hands-on and will give you ample opportunity to practice your negotiation skills by learning how expand the pie and create value. Leerdoelen
Learning objectives

Upon completion of the course, students are able to:
  • Understand and prepare effectively for different negotiation situations by applying    relevant knowledge;
  • Understand how cognitions, emotions, and motivations influence negotiations and utilize this knowledge when choosing a negotiation strategy;
  • Create and claim value in negotiations by knowing how to expand the size of the pie; 
  • Evaluate academic research on the relevant psychological mechanisms in negotiations.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Negotiation is one of the most important skills that a manager should have in his or her professional life. In our curriculum, however, this important skill has been underemphasized. This course aims to help you be a better negotiator. I will provide you with negotiation tools to effectively persuade others. The specific topics of this course include seeing and expanding the pie, dealing with someone who has a very different perspective on the world, disagreeing respectfully and productively, etc.

Disclaimer
  • This course aims at targeting students who do not have a background in behavioral economics. If you have such a background, I advise you not to sign up for this course.
  • This course may have some overlap with Dr. Hesam Fasaei’s Strategic Decision Making course. I advise you not to sign up for my course if you have taken that course.
Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  • Gaining an in-depth appreciation of becoming a better negotiator.
  • Understanding the foundations of how to identify and expand the pie.
  • Acquiring a tactical portfolio of influence tools that enable you to be more persuasive in communicating with the ones you are negotiating with.
  • Building competences in conflict management.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Social Networks shape many aspects of how people and organizations interact, take decisions, and ultimately perform. With the advent of Social Media (e.g., Facebook and Twitter) and with the increasing digitization of all forms of communication and business processes, Network Analytics has become a valued asset to better understand how different agents interact and how to best take advantage of the network structure to increase overall system performance. This course will cover the fundamentals of network science, the methods, theories, and the procedures for data collection and analysis in very large social networks. Covered topics include clustering, information diffusion, organizational design, viral marketing, social media and others.

This course provides the basics of network data analytics, including fundamental network- and node-level metrics, as well as more advanced analysis methods, with attention to the application areas where these can and have been used. Students will engage in in-class projects in which they collect and analyze network data using the tools and methods covered in class. Students will apply these methods to specific networks, such as social media networks (e.g., Twitter), co-worker networks, organization networks, and product networks. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
This course will teach you the fundamental skills for decision making based on social network data. Specifically, you will learn:
  • How to use R for analysis of network data;
  • How to represent network data;
  • Techniques and tools for social network analysis and visualization;
  • How do networks form;
  • Which types of network structures foster and hinder performance in specific contexts;
  • How to use social network data to inform decision making.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud In our current network society governments increasingly face so called ‘wicked problems’. Concrete examples of ‘wicked problems’ are the uncontrolled influx of refugees and its societal implications, attempts at inner city regeneration, conflicts over the construction or operation of public infrastructures (e.g., roads, airports and windmill parks), health and social problems like obesity, drug use, safety and criminality, and lack of coordination in elderly and youth care. These problems are characterized by:
  • The involvement of a large number and broad diversity of actors
  • The strong (resource) interdependencies between governments and other involved actors
  • The lack of consensus about the nature of the problem and the desired solutions
  • The complexity of the issues at stake and the lack of adequate and accepted information and expertise on these issues
These problems are addressed in networks of interdependent actors. The autonomous position of the actors and their (diverging) individual strategies makes decision- and interaction processes in networks complex. In the course Network Governance, we explore these complex governance processes in depth, drawing on theoretical concepts of network governance and practicing network analysis through the analysis of a concrete case.
Students will be introduced to theoretical concepts of governance networks and network governance to enable them to understand and analyze the interdependence between government and society. To that end, concepts such as networks, dependencies, perceptions and different aspects of the complexity of network governance processes will be dealt with.
Students will also learn to interpret, understand and analyze networks and the governance processes that take place within these networks. Finally, students will analyze, assess and design management strategies in order to influence networks and network processes. The interaction between theory and practice is the main focus of the course. In tutorials students will practice with the concepts discussed during lectures and use the concepts to make assignments and conduct an in-depth case analysis (the core of the paper to be written). Leerdoelen
After following this course students must be able to: 
  1. Describe in their own words what the core concepts of the Network Governance approach are and why they are relevant to the analysis of problem solving and public service delivery. 
  2. Explain the differences between the Network Governance approach and traditional approaches to problem solving and public service delivery, more specifically the traditional bureaucratic Public Administration model and New Public Management. 
  3. Assess real-world examples of complex decision-making processes using core concepts of the Network Governance approach.  
  4. Design network management strategies that promote collective action in situations characterized by interdependencies between actors.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud As the platformization of media industries continues around the globe, cultural production and digital consumer markets are increasingly disrupted by participatory platforms. Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube, and other participatory platforms transformed business models and the diffusion of content within the media industries. For instance, the ways in which cultural events are promoted and brands are advertised changed substantially. This practical research workshop examines how different stakeholders in the media industries seek to capitalize on the participatory dynamics of platforms. A defining feature of platforms is their application programming interface (API). The Facebook Cambridge Analytica data scandal irreversibly brought the role of APIs to public awareness. APIs facilitate the flows of data between platform owners, users, and third parties. API-stored data can be repurposed for media research and provide insights into the ‘popularity’ of content creators, their audience engagement, and their connected communities.

In this workshop, students are given the opportunity to explore social network data from pivotal platforms, such as Twitter, GitHub, and YouTube. They will learn how content creators pursue coordinated online strategies, such as campaigns, product placement, and audience enlargement. The data sets primarily contain information on content creators, which are considered as network nodes, and digital traces of their platform practices, such as ‘mention’, ‘reply’, ‘comment’, ‘retweet’ and ‘collaborate’, which are considered as network edges. All students will conduct an individual, small-scale case study in which they analyze network visualizations. In doing so, they will formulate a research question, search for appropriate literature, and collect and analyze relevant data to answer their research question.
  Leerdoelen Learning goals:
  • Students will be able to distinguish natively digital data and digitized data;
  • Students will learn to use advanced search operators for Twitter and YouTube content;
  • Students will be able to create and interpret network graphs in Gephi and Visone
  • Students will learn the state-of the art theory on the subject of the workshop.

Students have developed the skills to:
  • Design and execute a small-scale empirical study on a workshop theme;
  • Report on their findings in oral and written form;
  • Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research;
  • Consult media firms on strategies for online campaigns.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. A Genevsky', 'dr. MAS Boksem', 'LD van Brussel, MSc', 'prof.dr.ir. A Smidts']
text:
Inhoud Economics, psychology, and neuroscience are converging today into the unified discipline of Neuroeconomics with the aim of providing a single, general theory of human choice behaviour. Neuroeconomics can provide social scientists and future managers with a deeper understanding of how they make their own decisions, and how others decide. How is a “good” or “fair” decision evaluated by the brain? What does our brain perceive as valuable? How do we learn the value of features of our environment? Is it possible to predict the purchasing intentions of a consumer? Are we hard-wired to be risk-averse or risk-seeking?
Neuroscience combined with psychology, economics and management theory provides powerful models and advanced brain-research methods to explain how and why people make certain choices. Risky decision-making in financial markets, the role of emotions versus rationality, competition and cooperation in teams, consumer persuasion, are some of the central issues in this course in neuroeconomics. You will be provided with the most recent evidence from brain-imaging studies, and you will be introduced to the explanatory models behind them.
The course will consist of three modules. In Module 1: “Introduction to Neuroeconomics”, we discuss the history of neuroeconomics and provide a crash-course on the anatomy of the brain, as well as an introduction to neuroscience methods. In addition, we will investigate the balance between rationality and emotions, and provide a brief introduction into decision-theory form both a psychologist and an economist perspective. In Module 2: “How the Brain Decides”, students will be presented with the main theories and neuroscientific findings accounting for how the brain makes (optimal) economic choices. We will focus on the neural mechanisms of the computation of value and preference, and how the brain deals with risk and losses. In addition, this module focuses on social aspects of decision-making: how group-membership and social interactions shape individuals’ decision-making. Finally, the practical applications of brain research in the fields of economics, marketing, business, and other aspects of society will be discussed in Module 3: “The Brain in Society”.
Each lecture will be given by a researcher with specific expertise on the topic. Lecturers either have a background in cognitive neuroscience or in economics and management research, and they are all collaborating in the Erasmus Centre for Neuroeconomics (see our website for further information: www.erim.nl/neuroeconomics ).
Students are required to show active participation in the course by attending the lectures and actively participating in the discussion forum (see below). The basic concepts of the course will be examined by means of a written research proposal.
Leerdoelen After completion of this course, you will be able to:
 
  • Name and identify the brain areas involved in choice behaviour.
  • Select the appropriate (neuro)scientific method for investigating different aspects of choice behaviour.
  • Explain which cognitive processes (decision parameters, heuristics) produce certain biases in choice behaviour.
  • Name and identify the brain areas that constitute the brain’s reward and punishment systems.
  • Explain how these systems work together to produce choice behaviour and apply this knowledge to explain various choice phenomena.
  • Name and identify the brain mechanisms that are involved in social choice behaviour.
  • Explain individual differences in choice behaviour by referring to the underlying neurobiological mechanisms.
  • Apply your neuroscientific knowledge to come up with methods to improve choice behaviour in real life.

In short, you will be able to:
 
  • Understand and explain everyday choice behaviour in terms of the cognitive processes involved.
  • Understand and explain these cognitive processes in terms of the involved neurobiological mechanisms.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
This course introduces the interdisciplinary field of neuromarketing. This new and exciting area in marketing aims to understand the neurobiological mechanisms underlying customer responses to marketing actions, and to better predict customer behavior using brain markers.
 
Neuromarketing is proposed to reveal information about customer preferences and reactions to marketing actions that other techniques cannot provide (Ariely and Berns, 2010). This is based on the assumption that customers are not always able or willing to express their true preferences in questionnaires. Furthermore, measures of brain activation could assist in the early stages of the product development process thus reducing the likelihood of failures.
 
In recent years, the application of neuroimaging and psychophysical techniques in marketing has surged both in academia and in marketing practice. Modern brain imaging techniques of electroencephalography (EEG) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) are commonly applied, for example, to track the emotional response to brands and TV commercials, to assess which scenes of a commercial attract attention and are memorable, to evaluate the beauty of a package or how customers trade-off price and quality. Psychophysical techniques such as eye-tracking, galvanic skin response and heart rate measurement add additional insights into the customers’ heart and mind.
 
Currently, most marketers are not trained in these techniques and thus have difficulty in properly evaluating the strengths and weaknesses of these methods. Clients of neuromarketing companies may get easily impressed by colourful pictures of activations in the brain which may not be truly insightful or predictive. In this course we provide the student with an up to date insight into the current body of knowledge in consumer neuroscience and neuromarketing. Accordingly, this course will provide many hands-on opportunities to develop neuromarketing skills. In assignments, the main neuroimaging techniques of fMRI and EEG will be introduced. You will collect data and learn the basics of analyzing this data.
 
Reference
Ariely & Berns (2010), Neuromarketing: The hope and hype of neuroimaging in business, Nature Reviews Neuroscience, 11(4), 284-292
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • Understand the basic anatomy and working of the brain
  • Understand the main neural processes underlying consumer decision making and consumer reactions’ to marketing actions (i.e., branding, advertising, design and packaging, pricing, assortment)
  • Understand and explain the intuition behind the neuroimaging methods of fMRI and EEG
  • Ability to collect, analyze and report basic fMRI and EEG data
  • Understand and explain the intuition behind psychophysical methods (in particular, eye-tracking, face reading, heart rate and galvanic skin response)
  • Draw inferences from neuromarketing data in order to answer descriptive and predictive questions relevant to marketing managers
  • Explain and justify managerial recommendations from neuromarketing studies to non-technical audiences through written reports and presentations
  • Understand the main opportunities and challenges of modern neuroscientific and psychophysical methods for marketing purposes

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. M Andreatta', 'dr. RER Van der Hallen']
text:
Inhoud Brain damage can cause cognitive, emotional and behavioral dysfunctions. A clinical psychologist, who works in the mental healthcare sector, has most likely to deal with brain-damaged patients. Think for instance about injuries resulting from a car accident, or about people, who suffered a stroke or patients, who suffer from neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease.

During the block, you will study the anatomy of human brain, as well as the functions of the cortical and subcortical areas. In addition, you will be familiarized with the techniques applied in science and in clinical settings, which contribute to our understanding of the brain, and to the diagnoses of neuropsychological disorders.

Block commands 
During the course, students are required to 1) fill in weekly Individual Readiness Assurance Tests, 2) to attend the weekly team sessions, and 3) to provide peer feedback to all fellow team members. These activities are mandatory and will be evaluated with a pass/fail qualification.
  Leerdoelen
This block has three main learning goals 

• To know the structure and organization of the central nervous system (CNS).
• To link the brain anatomy to the psychological processes like sensory perception, motion, learning and memory, emotion, language, attention, and other executive functions.
• To apply the knowledge about brain anatomy and psychological processes to better understand the symptomatology of the neuropsychological disorders and their causes.
Belangrijk om te weten The language of instruction in the teaching groups is English or Dutch, depending on the registration for the national or international program. The exam will be however only in English.

course_title: Neurorevalidatie: diagnostiek, behandeling en bewegen als medicijn
college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['B.C. Drooger - Jongejan', 'dr. A.M.C. Sluijter', 'dr. G. Jansen', 'dr. M. van der Werf', 'dr. N. ter Hoeve', 'dr. R. Osterthun', 'drs. E. Grauwmeijer', 'K. Nieuwenhuis', "M. 't Hart - Bijl", 'R.F. Pangalila']

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud The way your brain works, governs how you interact with the world, how society works and what we consider as reality, among other things. So why not learn a little bit of how the brain works? This is a multidisciplinary course in which you will be able to define several concepts from the neuroscience perspective, such as sensory perception, the concept of “self”, behaviour, and learning and memory. You will further recognise how different disciplines, like Neuroeconomics, Psychology and Philosophy, apply neuroscientific knowledge in their practice. Finally, you might have the opportunity of participating in a (animal) brain bisection practical to bring into reality what you have learnt during the course.
Leerdoelen After completing the course students will be able to discuss the link between music (perception) and human movement, especially in terms of evolutionary auditory specialization, in terms of interpersonal coordination and in terms of the effects of musical training on the brain. Students will be able to argue that without movement, there is no music, neither played nor perceived. Students will have had an introduction to several behavioral measurement techniques, digital audio analysis, experiment design, as well as scientific reporting. Finally, students will be able to bridge gaps between research fields in the sense of applying existing research methods and questions to a field that these methods were not developed for.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Most students from RSM will be confronted with new business development at some stage in their careers. This course aims to serve as a pilot test for you, assessing your strength and weakness in entrepreneurial practices. To do so, this course will collaborate with multiple companies and provide tangible business projects for you, with the aim to address real business challenges related to new business development. As a result, you will face the full complexity of new business development. To assist you navigate the project, a reference contact from the company will actively work with you during the six weeks of the course.  

Course Materials
No textbook is required for this course. The course are highly practical.

Additional Information
  • The core component of this course is the project you work on. You are expected to draw upon your own experience and expertise (e.g. by bringing in relevant tools, methods, theories from prior courses, etc.) to address the new business development opportunities/challenges.  
  • The guest lectures will consist of exemplary venturing experiences and reflections at startups or established firms.  
  • All the workload comes from the project you and your team members will be working on, and assignments in the course function as milestones to facilitate your progress on your project.  
  • The grading has four components: final business plan (40%), presentation of the final business plan (25%), individual reflection (25%), and contribution added in the classroom (10%).  
  • The information in this document is under regular reservation. When you sign up, please check Canvas for the most-up-to-date information. 
  • You will be the unfortunate attendees of the course in which the professor does not know what he’ll be doing. But the course has been receiving super good evaluations in the past years. 
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • Developing a comprehensive understanding of the organizational problems that entrepreneurs must face when aiming for new business development. 
  • Gaining a critical attitude towards the understanding of new business development practices in context with significant time and resource constraints. 
  • Putting entrepreneurial theories into practice by interacting with the business community in a complex, real business case.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud Towards behavioural economics 2.0? Several proposals have been made to move (behavioural) economics beyond the stage in which economics has been enriched by psychological findings and insights. In this course, several directions are identified and discussed: Brains, Evolution, Morality, Complexity, Culture and Welfare & Policy. Leerdoelen
At the end of this course, students will have developed an informed and nuanced overview of several directions in which behavioral economics can further evolve. Testimony for this will have to be provided by writing an research paper in which students show that they have a clear idea about the about both the prospects (merits and demerits) of behavioural economics moving forward into one of these directions.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
lecturers: ['G Silvestri', 'MA Schouten, MSc', 'MJ de Pater', 'prof.dr. KEH Maas']
text:
Inhoud

The aim of this course is to explore new economic futures by critically engaging with innovative entrepreneurs and following academic debates of socio- economic transitions. Even though more and more companies acknowledge their responsibility to contribute to global issues like climate change, poverty and resource scarcity, they often struggle to develop alternative business models and value propositions that help to guide and accelerate transitions to a sustainable economy and society. Hence, in this minor, we focus on understanding transitions and the role traditional and transformative businesses can play in these long term change processes of economies, sectors and societies.
As part of the Minor we will address several points:
* We will provide you with an overview of research on sustainability transition theory, social entrepreneurship, new business models and new value propositions from an interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary perspective, combining insights from economics, management and transition studies.
* We will support you to become familiar with alternative business models, and ways how businesses change and innovate in response to societal transitions.
* We will support you to better understand how societal change occurs and to map sustainability transition dynamics.
* Business challenges and opportunities of diffusing such innovative business models will be discussed from an academic and practitioners’ perspective including financing, management and governance lenses.
* Attention will be paid to the value proposition of impact thinking and impact measurement.
* You will work in groups on an empirical study in which you will apply your new academic knowledge and insights on a practical case (i.e. carrying out a consultancy project to develop a business advice in collaboration with a social enterprise). At the end of the course, each group of students will pitch their ideas and suggestions to entrepreneurs and representatives from business during a “Dragon’s Den” event.
Examples are new business models based on circular/sharing economy, social entrepreneurship or impact investment.

Leerdoelen

1. Describe the complex nature of social, economic and environmental challenges of our society and explore the role of societal transitions;
2. Characterize theoretical concepts, frameworks and methods on sustainability transitions, new economic thinking and business models; 3. Explain the (potential) role of business as a transformative force using theories of new economic models, value propositions and societal transitions;
4. Assess debates around new economic thinking using transition and impact thinking;
5. Identify the ways a social entrepreneur can contribute to a new economy based on theories about new business models, value propositions and societal transitions

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Based on student evaluation we have fewer lecturers and the topics of the lecturers are better structured towards sustainability transitions, new economic thinking and social entrepreneurship. We have also rescheduled the assignments to make sure the students will receive feedback within two weeks. Belangrijk om te weten Related to the cooperation with the social entrepreneurs it might be needed to meet them which might lead to transport costs (public transport). As alternative it is always possible to have online meetings. There are no other additional costs related to the course. Extra If you want to participate in this minor, we expect you to be open minded, curious and – at times – provocative and interested in solving the grand challenges society is facing. You will engage in critical debates and be able to reflect critically upon offered theories. Multidisciplinary perspectives, applied research and problem oriented learning approaches have your interest. As this minor is delivered in English, you need to have a sufficient command of the English language in speech and writing to actively participate in class. We strongly encourage students from diverse disciplines to apply.
 
Several research centers contribute to this minor as well as the economic students association:
Impact Centre Erasmus
DRIFT
EFR

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This seminar is focused on understanding the impact of new communication technologies on the Marketing and Advertising Industry. This industry is continuously using creativity to face the challenges of an ever-changing media landscape that urges brands and companies to reinvent the way they communicate with their customers. During this course, we will explore how brands are taking advantage of the quick innovations in the communications and creative industries to persuade customers in new and innovative ways. We will also critically reflect on the value and implications of these new forms of branded communication. We will reflect on how these are perceived by customers but also how much value they have for brands. Finally, we will also learn how to apply the theoretical knowledge acquired during the course to design efficient new media marketing campaigns.
 
The NMMA strategies discussed in this course include: personalized advertising, branded entertainment, gamification and playful marketing, and influencer marketing.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding  of:
  • The impact of new communication technologies on the Marketing and Advertising Industry
  • The different theoretical perspectives on the study of NMMA
  • The value of scientific knowledge for the critical analysis and design of NMMA strategies and campaigns
Students have developed skills to:
  • Critically analyze the new ways brands and companies are communicating with consumers
  • Apply theoretical knowledge for the analysis of NMMA strategies and campaigns
  • Apply theoretical knowledge for the design of NMMA strategies and campaigns

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. DRS Ongenaert', 'dr. FGR De Keyzer', 'dr. J Vanhaelemeesch', 'dr. LA Borges Lima', 'FKS Robinson']
text:
Inhoud
New media and social media have become central to everyday life, and how these can be used effectively within international business has become an important topic for business and communication research. From mobile apps and gaming to social media including Instagram, Facebook and Twitter, new media have changed the way international business gets done. While these changes have transformed logistics, resource management and hiring practices, this course will specifically focus on how new media have affected (and been affected by) marketing practices and the growing importance of social media as a channel of strategic communication. That is, the course will focus on two areas. First, it will evaluate marketing practices that employ new media, most specifically the practices on social media through Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, YouTube, and more. Second, the course will look at a new wave of marketing strategies that involve influencers, participatory publics/audiences, gamification, and fandoms.
 
In the first few weeks of the course, students will be oriented to a practice theory focused approach to understanding the use of new media in context, exploring readings and examples ranging from traditional media to videogames to the rise of independent content creators. This is then further focused on the three focus areas within the course. During the latter part of the research workshop, students will engage in qualitative research focused on new media and international business, examining the practices and technologies involved in the marketing of specific media/mediated products – streaming content, videogames, apps, theme parks, and music, among others. They will, through the use of qualitative and/or mixed methods, empirically examine the ways in which companies and content creators promote themselves through social media as part of a marketing strategy, how they interface with each other and users in creating buzz about new products, how gamified advergames are used to enhance attraction (and also, at times, mislead consumers), and other related topics. In order to gain both conceptual and methodological knowledge, students will take several reading comprehension quizzes, engage in in-class exercises, group work, develop their own line of research, execute and present on research work that is subsequently integrated into a final research paper.
Leerdoelen Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:
  • How marketing and business practices shape markets through various technologies and techniques 
  • Differentiated levels of control (and their implications) attained by international businesses in the use of new and social media (with particular attention to marketing and human resources)
  • How new and/or social media choices affect the distribution and control of information and communication 
  • The use of empirical cases studies in studying new media practices

Students have developed skills to:
  • Develop and execute a small research project either focusing on new media and marketing or new media and workplace contexts
  • Effectively research new media practices through empirical case studies
  • Evaluate practices within international businesses, focusing on the potentials and problems that come with the use of new media
  • Define problematic potentials for practices and policies within international business in relation to new media 
  • Report their research findings in a scientifically substantiated manner
  • Work with (international) peers and reflect on their own development

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Back in the mid-1990s, the rapid popularization of the Internet had raised the hope of technologically-enhanced citizen engagement in political decision-making. How did the vision of an electronic democracy, where new media enable citizens to monitor and participate in the life of their polis, turn out in practice? On the one hand, our own use of new media is oriented towards consumption and entertainment. On the other, political content circulated online is often dubious or problematic, while political debates online often become heated and even toxic. From cyberwarfare and fake news, to citizen digital activism, online political communication appears to be in a state of constant transformation. Each year, the instructor focuses the course around a salient topic in the field of online political communication (e.g. deliberation; populism; etc.) asking how citizens and politicians engage in political talk online and to what effect on the quality of our democracies and or our polities. In addressing the topic, we focus on the ways in which new media both hinder and enable political communication. Since the secondary purpose of this course is to improve your empirical research skills, you develop and conduct a small research project on the topic of the course. You gain methodological knowledge and skill necessary for assessing and doing scientific research. The course thus improves your qualitative research knowledge and skill. Furthermore, the knowledge about online political communication gained in this course improves your own civic performance and prompts you to consider how, as a communication professional, you can help create democratic communication. Leerdoelen
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:
  1. Contemporary dynamics in political communication.
  2. The use of new media for political communication purposes.
  3. Qualitative research and its role in examining political communication.
Students have developed skills to:
  1. Design a qualitative research project.
  2. Collect and analyze data.
  3. Evaluate the data in a theoretically-informed manner.
  4. Report findings through oral presentations and written reports.
  5. Build arguments that synthesize and integrate knowledge of political communication.

course_title: New Media and the Creative Industries
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This is an exciting and transformative moment for creative industries across the globe. As the economics of media industries shift from advertising-based revenue models to subscriber-based revenue models, streaming platforms that provide different types of content directly to consumers are becoming increasingly important. For example, the global expansion of streaming video on-demand services like Netflix both reflect and drive change within traditional audiovisual media industries like television and film. Yet, the proprietary nature of streaming audience data and the near total lack of data transparency offered by streaming companies themselves creates a variety of challenges for media industry researchers. 
The main goal of this research workshop is to help students to overcome these challenges using the “production culture” approach. This approach, sometimes called media historiography, media industry studies, or trade press analysis, is grounded in the academic perspective that understands media industry discourse as centrally important to understanding media industry practice.
Students will learn how to gather and analyze relevant data about the creative industries from a variety of publicly available sources including but not limited to trade press articles, press releases, trade and popular press interviews, videos of industry events, and financial documents. Students will formulate a research question related to a specific streaming service situated within a broader streaming industry. Students will create a qualitative research design, collect and then analyze data. Their efforts culminate in an academic research paper.

  Leerdoelen

At the end of this research workshop, students will be able to:

  • Conduct an empirical qualitative research project
  • Produce an academically sound research paper in collaboration with (international) peers
  • Communicate their research findings through a formal academic presentation
  • Effectively research the creative industries by utilizing publicly available materials

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Entertainment and cultural products shape the identities of audiences and fans all over the world. Music, TV shows, movies, videogames and anime are all different ways of contacting with different cultures and connecting with strangers. In a time where nationalism and divisions are on the rise in some parts of the world, this course explores how people connect, share experiences and produce new content related to their favorite cultural products. How do fan groups and forums organize themselves online? How do cultural products create conflicts or encourage friendships? What is the impact of new media on community building? Do entertainment products help bridge tensions and reduce polarization between different groups?
​
Using quantitative content analysis, we will learn how to conduct research in the world of entertainment and explore the interactions between cultural products and audiences. Furthermore, students will learn that research about communities and new media is not limited to the field of entertainment, but that similar research methods and concepts can also be applied to other communication fields like brand communities and national identities. Leerdoelen Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:
  • The various ways that new media affect the field of culture and entertainment
  • How entertainment products contribute to build group identities, develop fandom, and connect different individuals and cultures
  • Different kinds of new media analysis
Students have developed skills to:
  • Analyze and evaluate (research on) the role of new media in the cultural industries and their influence on shaping identities and creating communities
  • Translate theoretical notions into an empirical research design
  • Empirically examine interaction practices and identities (culture and entertainment-related) 
  • Apply relevant research methods and techniques covered in the methodological core courses (quantitative)
  • Report research findings in a scientifically grounded manner

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Perceptions of the political are evolving due to widespread transformations in society and new media play an important role in these transformations. Yet, the debate on whether advances in new media technologies are impacting democracy positively or negatively remains complex and open to constant revision. This seminar looks at the role that new media (particularly social media, but also more classic forms like websites and blogs) play within such an evolving political context with a focus on political campaigns. Throughout the course, we build a theoretical background allowing us to assess contemporary dimensions of (internet) politics. For our discussions, we focus on three types of campaigns: electoral, grassroots (or citizen-led), and public information campaigns. Each week, we introduce the relevant debates and classical concepts associated with each type of campaign. We then explore how these debates and concepts are affected by the reliance on new media. In the end, this helps us inquire into how political campaigns are evolving (or not) in relation to new media, and how communication via new media impacts the political world.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • Current theoretical perspectives on the intersections between new media and political campaigns.
  • The role of new media in a democratic society.
  • Common research methods of analyzing the role of new media in political campaigns.
Students have developed the ability/propensity to:
  • Analyze new media in a broad political framework.
  • Critically reflect on the impact of new media in the political arena.

course_title: New Research Methods in Data Analytics
college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

In this course students are introduced to various advanced marketing research techniques.
In marketing often rich data are available in customer databases or in reviews and blogs on the web. The techniques introduced in this course enable firms to transform these data into knowledge.
At the same time little information is available about consumer preferences for new products. In these cases efficient data collection and analysis are needed to obtain knowledge at low cost.
Students will develop a deeper understanding of the techniques introduced in the course. They will also learn how to design and analyze conjoint choice experiments to study consumer preferences. Finally they will learn how to present consumer preference research results and to evaluate and interpret the outcomes of such research.

Leerdoelen
  • Students will develop a deeper understanding of several marketing research techniques related to online marketing and consumer preference measurement.
  • Students will learn how to design and analyze conjoint choice experiments to study consumer preferences.
  • Students will practice how to present consumer preference research results and to evaluate and interpret the outcomes of such research.
  • Students will practice writing a team research report.
Extra No major changes, except possibly in guest lectures.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

Dit vak behandelt het optimaliseren van functies met en zonder nevenvoorwaarden, zowel vanuit theoretisch als praktisch oogpunt. De volgende onderwerpen zullen langskomen:

  • Analyse van problemen zonder nevenvoorwaarden
  • Lijnzoekmethoden
  • Newtons methode en varianten
  • Optimalisatie van niet-differentieerbare functies
  • Analyse van problemen met nevenvoorwaarden
  • Algoritmes voor problemen met nevenvoorwaarden

Dit vak maakt gebruik van kennis van kennis van FEB21023 Vector Calculus en FEB21011 Inleiding Programmeren, en is nodig voor FEB22004 Econometrie 1, FEB22005 Econometrie 2 en FEB22009 Basiswerkcollege Econometrie en Operations Research.

Leerdoelen

Na het afronden van dit vak kan u:

  • Bewijzen wat het onbegrensde minimum van een continue functie is (als het analytisch gevonden kan worden);
  • Een lijnzoekalgoritme implementeren om het minimum van een continue functie te benaderen (als het niet analytisch gevonden kan worden);
  • Uitleggen wat de verschillende opties voor lijnzoeken zijn;
  • Bewijzen van het minimum is van een continue functie op een algebraïsche verzameling;
  • Uitleggen welke types algoritmes in de praktijk worden gebruikt om continue optimalisatieproblemen op te lossen;
  • Het duale probleem van een continu optimalisatieprobleem opstellen;
  • Logisch correcte theoretische bewijzen creëren in de context van niet-lineair optimaliseren;
  • Simpele algoritmes implementeren in Matlab.
Extra Geen extra kosten: de universiteit heeft een licentie voor MATLAB.

course_title: Noise - Understanding errors in human judgment and prediction
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
Companies and institutions are often surprised when confronted with the variation of judgements and decisions of their members and employees. For instance, sales forecast, performance ratings and hiring proposals will often vary greatly between individuals. In most cases, this variation is considered noise, i.e. unwanted variation around the true value, that is risking the quality of managers decision processes. To reduce noise, however, the sources of variation must first be identified to second, implement tactics to reduce variation. In contrast to that, most companies are not even aware about the amount of noise in their processes.
In this course, we will study different sources of noise in human judgement and decision making. We will understand differences between stable, e.g. manager A always gives a more lenient evaluation, and random, e.g. managers will not always enter precisely the same numbers, sources of variation and learn techniques to reveal the amount of noise and diminish noise if desired. To that goal, the course discusses theories of judgment and decision making, statistical models of choice and judgment, and their managerial implications.
Accordingly, the background literature is spread across psychology, marketing and economics but mostly related to the recently published book NOISE by Nobel laureate Daniel Kahneman, Olivier Sibony and Cass Sunstein.
The course consists of two sessions per week. One of these sessions is a more theory heavy lecture with a short discussion and clarification questions. The second session is a more interactive workshop. Here students are asked to implement or experience the newly gained knowledge, also with the statistical programming language R. No prior knowledge of R is required to take the course, but some experience is advantageous.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  1. Using R to analyse and simulate noise in judgement and prediction
  2. Know what can cause noise in judgement and prediction
  3. Understand the dangers of noisy judgements for institutions and companies

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Companies increasingly supplement financial performance measurement and disclosure with non-financial information on aspects of their business activity. Examples include, but are not limited to, forward-looking nonfinancial indicators such as customer satisfaction, employee turnover, and online engagement, as well as metrics related to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) dimensions. Nonfinancial metrics can provide relevant information to stakeholders that help to broaden the scope of performance measurement, contributing to an integrated perspective on performance that has implications for internal decision-making, investors, and other external stakeholders, as well as, more broadly, firms’ roles within society.

This course focuses on the importance of nonfinancial performance information. It takes a multitude of different perspectives to answer the question of what role different nonfinancial performance measures play for different stakeholders. We start by taking a “traditional” economic perspective and exploring how different nonfinancial performance measures can be direct antecedents of financial performance. From this perspective, we will discuss linking strategy with performance measurement. Second, we will take the perspective of digital transformation. Here we will explore firms’ changing needs for performance measures beyond profitability, the particular needs of firms with digital business models, and the growing possibilities to employ novel, digital measures of performance. Third, we will move our focus to how nonfinancial performance can indirectly contribute to financial performance and discuss how corporate governance contributes to optimized managerial decision making and value creation. Fourth, we will move beyond the relevance of nonfinancial performance for the individual firm to include a broader perspective on the relevance of ESG performance for various stakeholders and society at large. Finally, we take the perspective of reporting to reflect on the needs of various groups of stakeholders and learn about forms of mandated and voluntary nonfinancial disclosure around the world.

Overall, students in this course will learn about—and critically reflect on—the role of nonfinancial performance analysis for firms’ internal decision-making, valuation by investors, and society at large, thereby deepening their understanding of value creation and the important role that finance and accounting play in this regard.

 

Leerdoelen

After following this course, students can:

  • Understand how nonfinancial performance can be measured and are familiar with frequently used non-financial performance metrics.
  • Understand how nonfinancial performance measures drive internal decision-making and value creation.
  • Understand how digital transformation changes companies’ needs and possibilities to measure performance.
  • Are familiar with the emergence of new, digital measures of nonfinancial performance and their growing importance for firm value in digital markets.
  • Comprehend the role of solid governance structures and executive compensation design in enhancing performance.
  • Evaluate the (economic) value creation based on reported ESG / non-financial performance.
  • Comprehend arguments for the importance of ESG performance beyond firm-level economic rationale.
  • Understand current legal requirements regarding the reporting of nonfinancial metrics.
  • Reflect on the desirability and circumstances determining the useful application of non-financial performance metrics and ESG reporting frameworks.
Skills
  • Design a balanced, value-creating performance reporting system including non-financial indicators.
  • Analyze and evaluate the informativeness and value relevance of nonfinancial performance indicators.
  • Reflect on the strength of a firm’s governance system, pointing out its strengths and weaknesses for ESG firm performance.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

This course considers the optimisation of functions with and without constraints, both in theory and in practice. The following topics will be covered:

  • Analysis of unconstrained problems
  • Line search methods
  • Newton’s method and variants
  • Optimisation of non-differentiable functions
  • Analysis of constrained problems
  • Algorithms for constrained problems

This course uses knowledge of FEB21023X Vector Calculus and FEB21011X/S Introduction to Programming, and is required for FEB22004X Econometrics 1, FEB22005X Econometrics 2 and FEB22009X/S Introductory Seminar Econometrics and Operations Research.

Leerdoelen

By the end of the course, you will be able to

  • Prove what the unconstrained minimum of a continuous function is (if it can be found analytically);
  • Implement a line search algorithm to approximate the minimum of a continuous function (if it cannot be found analytically);
  • Explain what the different options for line search are;
  • Prove what the minimum is of a continuous function on an algebraic set;
  • Explain what types of algorithms are used in practice to solve continuous optimisation problems;
  • Determine the dual of a continuous optimisation problem;
  • Create logically valid theoretical proofs in the context of non-linear optimisation;
  • Implement simple algorithms in Matlab.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar No major changes. Extra No additional costs: the university has a MATLAB license

course_title: Non-market Strategy: CSR and Corporate Political Activities
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
​This course addresses a variety of political and social (i.e. non-market) boundaries, which, when considered along with market boundaries, help us understand why some firms thrive and others struggle. The non-market is a sometimes-neglected arena, which can severely limit or enable firms in doing business and influence their strategy. Eventually non-market boundaries can affect firm success, while they are particularly challenging to navigate since non-market actors differ in their motives, objectives and tactics relative to conventional market actors. Overall, the non-market opens up questions calling for strategic answers: How do firms incorporate interests of non-market actors, who are not (primarily) concerned about wealth maximization? How do firms draw the line between and manage their ‘duty’ to their constituents (i.e. non-market strategy) and their obligation to shareholders (i.e. market strategy)? What are the benefits and perils of corporate political and social engagement? Ultimately, is the management of non-market interests a means to an end, or an end in itself? In this elective, we will address these questions and discuss how firms are affected, and how they can themselves affect their non-market context. This will help us understand non-market strategy, why some firms thrive, while similar ones may struggle in the politically and socially colored market.  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
At the end of the course, students will be able to: 
  • Understand firm strategy in the context of firm interactions with non-market stakeholders who do not have profit maximization as their primary objective. 
  • Discuss different non-market strategies, as well as the integration of market and non-market strategies. 
  • Analyze key issues faced by firms in the non-market context. 
  • Evaluate firms’ non-market issues with strategic tools and methods. 
  • Devise a strategic plan to address a firm’s issues in the non-market.
