college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Organizational design is an everyday, ongoing activity and a challenge for every executive, whether managing a global enterprise or a small work team. Globalization, worldwide competition, deregulation, increased focus on sustainability, political risks, and ever-new technologies including digitalization, artificial intelligence (AI), robots and machine learning drive ongoing designs and redesigns of organizations. The executive response to the many challenges has been many new forms of organizational design: virtual, learning, modular, cellular, network, alliance, or spaghetti – to name a few. New organizational forms challenge old ways of organizing. Yet, fundamental design principles underlie any well-functioning organization. Research on the relationship between organization design and performance shows that approximately 30 percent of the variation in performance can be explained by the organizational design. It is therefore important to get the design right. 

Organizations require a design – including digital and self-organizing organizations. The fundamentals are: What are our goals? What are the basic tasks? Who makes which decisions? What is the structure of communication, and what is the incentive structure? Who has access to resources? Who has the formal responsibility? In terms of deciding who does what when, the “who” in today’s companies may be an individual, a team, or an intelligent robot, the what may be cloud-based services, and the when, in terms of timing, may be determined by the need for an ever-speedier response.

In this course, we will deal with strategic and organizational design as a managerial approach to demands for change in the organization. The concepts and theories in organizational Design is presented in the context of the multi-contingency approach and its application in a dynamic perspective. The multi-contingency model is following the information-processing paradigm where strategic and organizational fit and misfit are important concepts. A fit is an alignment between the organization and its environment, strategy, technology, management style or size. The theory of fit provides management with an opportunity to assess the organization design and change it regularly. The issues include multi-dimensional relationships, non-linearity and longitudinal perspectives - all important elements in studies of new forms of organization. 
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The course gives the student a thorough understanding of the concepts and theories within the area of Organizational Design. The student is also provided with competences to setup a diagnostic and design process in a company project from a dynamic and change perspective. Further the student will also have acquired skills to actually carry out a diagnostic and design process including collecting, analyzing and interpreting data.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Sinds het begin van de 20ste eeuw zijn psychologen met een kritische blik ‘het organiseren van werk’ gaan bestuderen. Wat is eigenlijk een organisatie? Werknemer Jan vindt dat zijn organisatie op een gevangenis lijkt, werknemer Piet vindt zijn bedrijf net een politieke partij. Deze verschillen in perceptie hebben met diverse `harde` en `zachte` factoren te maken. Denk maar aan (in volgorde van hard naar zacht) de hiërarchische relaties of formele machtsverhoudingen tussen medewerkers, de werkvormen, de wijze waarop medewerkers met elkaar communiceren, het geheel van ongeschreven normen en waarden, en informele machtsverhoudingen die er heersen.
Een belangrijke  vraag in organisatiepsychologie is hoe je een goede diagnose van een organisatie uitvoert. Daarom, zullen we ook aandacht besteden aan kwalitatieve methodes (zoals de casestudy methodiek) en kwantitatieve methodes (zoals het gebruik vragenlijsten voor het meten van organisatiecultuur).
 
Organisaties zijn geen losstaande entiteiten: ze evolueren onder invloed van economische, technologische en maatschappelijke impulsen. Denk maar aan het fuseren of het afslanken van bedrijven, de invloed van ontwikkelingen binnen de informatietechnologie, etc.
Organisatieverandering, –innovatie en de invloed op de diagnose en adviesverlening zijn eveneens belangrijk thema’s die organisatiepsychologen bestuderen.
 
Tot slot, het bestuderen van organisaties is een interdisciplinaire aangelegenheid: niet alleen psychologen maar ook sociologen, economen, bedrijfsdeskundigen en zelfs antropologen zijn actief op dit terrein. Zo zullen we thema’s bestuderen die nauw aansluiten bij de organisatiekunde zoals theorieën over organiseren, organisatievormen en -denkbeelden (denk aan de percepties van Jan en Piet!). Toch richten we ons hoofdzakelijk op datgene wat de psycholoog over de arbeidsorganisatie te vertellen heeft.
 
Alles bij elkaar, zullen we aandacht besteden aan het macroniveau van organisaties (organisatiestructuur, -strategie, -cultuur, -verandering en -innovatie) en het microniveau van organisaties (werknemerspercepties van oneerlijkheid, destructieve en constructieve werkgedrag, creativiteit enz.) Leerdoelen De algemene doelstelling is het verwerven van kennis en inzicht in de voornaamste psychologische basisconcepten en –theorieën over de structuur, strategie, cultuur, dynamiek, verandering, innovatie en diagnose van arbeidsorganisaties in relatie tot hun omgeving. Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
Organisations are constantly faced with external pressures to change their policies and practices – voiced by various stakeholders in their environment. Some of these pressures – so-called institutional pressures – will drive an organisation to become more similar to other organisations and adhere to state-of-the-art ways of doing things. Other pressures – competitive pressures – will instead drive an organisation to become more different from other organisations and develop new ways of doing things. And yet other pressures – normative pressures – will drive an organisation to position itself with respect to the moral order of society. Many organisational change programs – such as BPE, TQM, ERP implementations, innovation management programmes, mergers and acquisitions, sustainability standards, CSR programmes, and others – are the result of organisations’ efforts to deal with such manifold pressures from their environment.
How, under these conditions, should leaders steer an organisation’s development and change? Doing so raises difficult questions for leaders. How can their organisation walk the tightrope of adhering to established ways of doing things whilst also being distinct from their competitors? How much should their organisation change to conform with its environment? And how much should it rather change in opposition to its environment? And how may it even become a force for change within its environment, changing not only itself but also other organisations?
This course addresses these questions and in doing so develops a bird’s-eye-view of organisational responses to pressures for change, conceptualizing the organisation as embedded into different environments. It will integrate core theoretical concepts, including from institutional theory and strategic management, to help you understand how organisations respond to external pressures through changing their policies and practices.
 

Leerdoelen

Learning Objectives

  • Explain how organisations are embedded in their environment and how external pressures for change are caused
  • Evaluate different organisational responses to environmental pressures
  • Critically evaluate organisations’ ability to respond positively to pressures for change and themselves become a force for positive change in society
  • Develop theoretically sound real-life recommendations for responses to external pressures

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Hardly a day goes by without newspapers, NGOs, or government regulators calling out organizations and their leaders for behaviours – such as bribery and corruption, human rights violations, mistreatment of employees, environmental damage, and many others – that cause harm and break the law or violate ethical standards. Such organisational misconducts – and the scandals around them – are of great societal relevance because of how frequently they occur and because of the harm they can cause. Think only about a few prominent examples, such as the VW emissions scandal, the BP oil spill, or the Siemens corruption scandal. In fact, considering the harm that comes from organisational misconduct, its prevalence is quite astonishing and understanding its causes is highly important. In this course, we will thus focus on understanding why organizations engage in misconduct and when misconduct is publicized and punished – or not. We will analyse these issues using state-of-the-art academic research and selected case studies, considering in particular two contrasting perspectives: one that sees misconduct as abnormal, resulting from deliberate decisions of corrupted individuals in perverted organisational cultures; and another that sees misconduct as normal, resulting from boundedly rational and boundedly ethical behaviour of ordinary people embedded in common organisational structures. 

 
 

 

Leerdoelen

After completing this course, participants will be able to… 

  • Recognize and distinguish the main types of organisational misconduct and scandal. 
  • Understand and compare different explanations of organisational misconduct. 
  • Understand when or when not organisational misconduct is scandalized and/or punished. 
  • Identify and analyse ways through which misconduct could be mitigated, either by organizations themselves or by their external stakeholders.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The course Organisational Theory and Dynamics builds on prior courses such as Organisational Behavior and HRM. The course covers two themes as already indicated in the title. The first theme is about analysing and diagnosing the (social) structure and design elements in an organisation. New forms of organising will be elaborated as well. This is the core of organisation theory.
In the second theme we will focus on a more dynamic perspective of an organisation. This theme will cover the broad topic of organisational change. Various approaches to implement change and contextual influences on change such as culture and politics will be discussed.

Although concepts in organisation theory and dynamics are easy to understand and a bit like open doors, they require careful thinking when really using and applying them in ‘real-life’ and complex organisations. During this course you are asked to do both – studying the main theoretical concepts based on a custom-made book and also applying them. For this last objective, the lectures will be complemented with interactive sessions that include Q & A, quizzes and case discussions. The case ‘Housing Anywhere’ will be discussed as part of organization theory – this case is about the design of an organisation, internal alignment and coordination processes. Another case called "Strategic Changes at Royal IHC: Causes, Effects, Reactions and Possible Solutions" is covering a real-life change project as it was happening at IHC from approx. 2015 until 2020. This case is designed in an interactive way meaning that you will be asked to think about change processes at IHC and answer questions provided about them. Various angles, as represented by different stakeholders (e.g. top management, employees etc.), are taken to provide a multifaceted view on the course of action during change processes. You will work on questions about this case individually without grading and will be able to compare your answers with correct answers provided throughout the course. Complementing this we will conduct in-class interactive sessions where solve different aspects of the case and discuss your questions and comments.

The goals of the interactive sessions are, first, to stimulate the link between theory and practice on an analytical level and, second, to use theoretical concepts for developing and critically discuss solutions as they were chosen in practice. The lectures together with the textbook and the cases are the building blocks for the interactive sessions and ultimately prepare for the written test.
  Leerdoelen After completing this course successfully, you will be able to:
  • Understand the historical development and content of the most relevant concepts in organisation theory and change such as
    • Organisational social structure
    • Organisational technology
    • Power and politics in organisations and change
    • Organisational conflict
    • Categories of organisational change
    • Directed and facilitated change
    • Communicating change
  • Relate theoretical concepts to a predefined situation from practice
  • Demonstrate how choices regarding organisational structure have an impact on coordination and alignment among organisational units
  • Develop recommendations for an appropriate organisational social structure
  • Analyse specific but complex change problems

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Course overview

Current historical and political events show us how the study of social movements is more relevant than ever. Black Lives Matter, MeToo and Extinction Rebellion are only but the most recent examples of organized forms of collective action powerfully challenging the status quo in the social and environmental domains of modern societies.

Going beyond the confrontational nature of social movements, organizations (such as in the profit, nonprofit or public sector) can leverage and cooperate with social movements to create opportunities for social change in their fields and in broader society.

The course seeks to provide students with a general understanding of social movements, their impact in driving social and environmental change, and how organizations can interact with them in tackling some of the grand challenges of our time.

Leerdoelen

Learning goals

After following this course, students will be able to:

  • Distinguish different types of social movements and recognize the drivers behind their birth, growth and eventual success/ failure.
  • Understand the impact of social movements in driving (or reacting to) social change and tackling current societal and environmental grand challenges
  • Understand the impact and implications of social movements’ activities for organizations, in particular by looking at organizations as targets of social movements, organizations as sights of social movements, and organizations and market opportunities as outcomes of social movements.
  • Identify opportunities for organizations to collaborate with social movements in driving social change and tackling grand challenges.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
In dit blok geven we een introductie in de Arbeids- en Organisatiepsychologie. De meeste volwassen mensen brengen een aanzienlijk deel van hun tijd door op hun werk. Aan de centrale plek van werk in het leven dankt de A&O-psycholoog zijn bestaan. Met haar 100-jarige bestaan is de A&O-psychologie een jonge discipline binnen de psychologie. In die 100 jaar hebben we veel geleerd. Honderd jaar geleden nog dachten we dat arbeiders lui waren en met harde hand in het gareel gehouden moesten worden. Onze vroege vakgenoten hielden zich bijvoorbeeld bezig met het ontleden van taken om nauwkeurig te kunnen zeggen hoe en in welk tempo arbeiders handelingen moesten uitvoeren. Dit waren de hoogtijdagen van de lopende band. Pas later realiseerde men zich hoe frustrerend deze manier van werken kon zijn. Er kwam aandacht voor "intrinsieke motivatie", afwisselend werk en sociale relaties. De moderne A&O-psycholoog besteedt veel aandacht aan thema’s als werving en selectie, samenwerken, zelfontplooiing, plezier in het werk en arbeid en gezondheid.
 
Leerdoelen Dit blok is een kennismaking met de belangrijkste deelgebieden van de A&O psychologie:
de arbeidspsychologie, de organisatiepsychologie en de personeelspsychologie. Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
In Blok 2.8 bestuderen we menselijke prestaties op de werkplek. In het bijzonder onderzoeken we wat prestatie is, hoe het ingeschat, geëvalueerd en ontwikkeld wordt gedurende de professionele loopbaan.  

De volgende thema’s komen aan bod: (1) wat verstaan we onder werkprestaties? Hoe kunnen we prestaties en potentieel beoordelen en wat zijn de valkuilen (performance Appraisal)? (2 & 3) Wat zijn goede voorspellers voor prestatie? (4) Wat zijn belangrijke kenmerken waaraan training moet voldoen, hoe kun je mensen het beste iets leren? (5) Hoe kunnen we prestaties op de werkplek verbeteren en behouden (beloning). (6) Welke fundamentele biologische of evolutionaire processen kunnen een rol spelen bij prestatie en prestatiebeoordeling. (7) Hoe verlopen loopbanen (carrières) en hoe kan men werknemers begeleiden tijdens loopbanen (loopbaantheorieën, loopbaancounseling) (8) Hoe zit het met geslachtsverschillen op de werkvloer. Dit laatste onderwerp is een soort overkoepelend thema waarin alle andere thema’s naar voren kunnen komen (loopbanen, prestatie, beloning, etc.). 

De bovengenoemde thema’s hebben allemaal betrekking op aspecten van Human Resource Management (HRM). Je zult echter merken dat de thema’s zeker ook voor toekomstige onderwijs-, klinische, biologisch/cognitieve en arbeidspsychologen relevant zijn.

Leerdoelen
Blok 2.8 belicht belangrijke thema`s die bijdragen tot de ontwikkeling van prestatie op de werkplek. Hieronder vind je per thema de voornaamste doelstellingen van het blok:
 
  • Prestaties op de werkplek (performance concepts, performance theory)
    • Je hebt inzicht in de concepten ‘werkprestatie’, ‘competentie’ en ‘potentieel’
    • Je hebt kennis van de instrumenten die gebruikt worden om potentieel op de werkplek in te schatten
    • Je kan prestatiebeoordelingen beoordelen
    • Je hebt inzicht in beoordelingsinstrumenten
  • Voorspellers van werkprestatie
    • Je kent de wetenschappelijke stand van zaken met betrekking tot capaciteit en persoonlijkheidsvoorspellers van goede werkprestaties
  • Beloning (pay for performance)
    • Je hebt inzicht in de psychologische theorieën van beloning
    • Je hebt kennis van het meest gehanteerde beloningssysteem in Nederland
  • Fundamenteel psychologische processen op het werk
    • Je hebt inzicht in welke fundamentele evolutionair-psychologische processen een rol kunnen spelen in arbeidsprestatie en in de selectie van personeel 
  • Loopbanen en loopbaancounseling (careers & career counseling)
    • Je hebt inzicht in en kan bevindingen uit de voornaamste psychologische loopbaantheorieën toepassen op loopbanen van mensen
  • Werkgerelateerde geslachtverschillen
    • Je hebt inzicht in het glazen plafond en factoren die de loopbanen van vrouwen beïnvloeden
    • Je bent bekend met verschillende theorieën op het gebied van man/vrouw verschillen op de werkplek
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Across the globe the natural environment is in an increasingly precarious state. In many natural environment areas, humanity has already crossed the boundaries leading to an increased risk of generating large-scale abrupt or irreversible environmental changes.

Organizations – entities comprising one or more individuals with a particular purpose – such as businesses, institutions, or associations across many different sectors and in various forms have been shown to play a role in this development. How they behave can have substantial implications for the natural environment around us.

But how exactly are organizations and the natural environment related? What implications do organizational actions have for the natural environment, and the natural environment for organizations? And how do organizations respond to and manage their relationship with the natural environment?

In this elective we consciously move beyond the frequently and broadly discussed topic of climate change and pay particular attention to a range of extremely important yet often less examined natural environment topics, including the themes of water, (chemical) pollution, and biodiversity (loss).

In so doing, the aim is to extend your understanding of natural environment issues in and around organizations and to enable you to have informed managerial conversations on an array of natural environment issues in your roles as future organizational leaders. Further, this course will also develop your skillset by getting you to learn about and then apply a range of tools to assess natural environment issues. Leerdoelen Learning goals
After following this course, you will be able to:
  • Explain how organizations and the natural environment are connected holistically.
  • Analyze the challenges and opportunities for organizations attempting to integrate natural environment issues.
  • Apply natural environment analytical tools in order to make informed organizational decisions.
  • Evaluate different organizational approaches and strategies for addressing natural environment topics.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Course overview 

Grand challenges are complex global problems that require collaborative and collective efforts to addressing them. In this course, we approach an understanding of grand challenges, such as climate change, inequality, global health or displacement, and examine how they differ from other Business and Management problems. The focus of the course will be on different forms of innovation to address these grand challenges. In particular, we will explore topics such as technologies for good, social innovation and social entrepreneurship, collaborative innovation and ecosystem innovation. We will examine the potential of these innovations for addressing grand challenges but also analyze the limitations or ‘dark sides’ of such innovations. We end the course with a session on imagining desirable futures This course builds on previous courses such as ‘Innovation Management’ and ‘Organisational Theory and Dynamics’ and is for students who are eager to broaden their horizon beyond typical business and management problems and apply their knowledge, analytical and innovative skills to approach the critical problems of our times, in line with RSM’s mission to be a force for positive change in the world.

 

Leerdoelen

Learning Goals

After completing this course, participants will be able to:

  • Recognize and describe grand challenges and discuss their complexities and characteristics
  • Understand and explain different forms of innovation to address grand challenges
  • Analyse and evaluate the potential and limitations of these innovations for addressing grand challenges
  • Design a poster to showcase the analysis

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Technological change (e.g., new advancements in Artificial Intelligence or the development of mRNA technology for the treatment of diseases) leads to major challenges and opportunities for firms in different industries. In recent years, the investments in industrial research and development (R&D) have increased in many sectors. To provide a beneficial organizational context for the exploration, assimilation, retention, and exploitation of new technological knowledge, firms need to consider specific organizational and management concepts, which are addressed in detail in this course.

The students gain detailed knowledge about fundamental issues concerning strategies, organizational capabilities, and organizational designs with respect to technological change. Among other aspects, the course addresses organizational issues related to technology forecasting, timing of entry, overcoming resistance to change, firm adaptability and agility, R&D processes and structures, absorption of new external knowledge, as well as external commercialization of internally created technologies.  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
After completing this course, students should be able to:
  • Understand why and how some companies survive technological changes, and others do not.
  • Analyze various organizational and management dimensions of technological transformation in businesses.
  • Understand and apply relevant concepts and tools related to the exploration, retention, and exploitation of new technological knowledge to solve real company case problems associated with strategic challenges.
  • Evaluate the effects of different organizational design elements on companies’ technological transformations.
  • Recommend strategies for companies to take advantage of technological disruptions on the basis of relevant concepts and case studies and reflect critically on own conclusions.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
Blok 2.7 is het logisch vervolg op blok 1.6 Orthopedagogiek I. In Blok 1.6 heb je kennis gemaakt met de discipline van de Orthopedagogiek als oorspronkelijk handelingswetenschap en tegenwoordig steeds meer als empirische wetenschap. Daarnaast ben je bekend met de grondleggers en werkvelden van de orthopedagogische praktijk en het gebruik van de diverse cycli bij theorievorming, diagnostiek en hulpverlening door orthopedagogen. Blok 2.7 is een verbreding en verdieping van orthopedagogische kennis en handelen met als centraal thema stoornissen bij jeugdigen. 
De primaire taak van orthopedagogen is opvoeders te ondersteunen in de opvoeding van hun kinderen zodanig dat kinderen zich optimaal kunnen ontwikkelen en ontplooien. Wanneer kinderen een ontwikkelings- of andere stoornis hebben, kan dit leiden tot een verzwaarde opvoedingsopgave of -last en rust er een zware verantwoordelijkheid op de schouders van de orthopedagoog om opvoeders (ouders, andere gezins- en familieleden, maar ook groepsleiders en leerkrachten) op wetenschappelijk onderbouwde en cultureel gepaste wijze te ondersteunen in hun opvoedingstaken. 
In dit blok worden de meest voorkomende gedragsproblemen, ontwikkelingsstoornissen, persoonlijkheidsstoornissen en leerproblemen behandeld aan de hand van prevalentie, vermeende oorzaken vanuit diverse wetenschappelijke perspectieven, co-morbiditeit, prognose, (de geschiedenis van) diagnostiek en meest belangrijke of populaire vormen van behandeling of ondersteuning met betrekking tot deze problemen en stoornissen. 
Kinderen met internaliserende en externaliserende gedragsproblemen (zoals angst, depressie, Conduct Disorder/ODD) en ontwikkelingsstoornissen (zoals Autisme Spectrum stoornissen, ADHD), persoonlijkheidsstoornissen (zoals borderline persoonlijkheidsstoornis) en leerproblemen (dyscalculie, dyslexie) staan centraal in dit blok. De focus ligt op het orthopedagogisch handelen. Er zal dus worden bekeken hoe zo’n probleem is ontstaan, wat dit betekent voor het kind, voor de ouders en voor de directe leefomgeving van het kind en hoe, vanuit een orthopedagogisch perspectief, het kind, zijn/haar gezin en de bredere sociale omgeving ondersteund kunnen worden. 
Naast de blokken 2.6 en 2.8 maak je in dit blok kennis met de vraagstukken waar pedagogen en onderwijswetenschappers in de beroepspraktijk voor staan en welke instrumenten en interventies daar veelal bij gebruikt worden.
Leerdoelen
Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:
  • een beschrijving te geven van kenmerken, prevalentie, prognose, co-morbiditeit van ontwikkelingsstoornissen, (internaliserende en externaliserende) gedragsproblemen, persoonlijkheidsstoornissen en leerproblemen en deze stoornissen/problemen onderling te vergelijken (eindtermen 3 en 5);
  • de meeste belangrijke wetenschappelijke theorieën en verklaringen vanuit diverse perspectieven voor deze ontwikkelingsstoornissen, (internaliserende en externaliserende) gedragsproblemen, persoonlijkheidsstoornissen en leerproblemen te beschrijven en de daarmee verband houdende wetenschappelijke onderzoeken te beschrijven en deze theorieën en verklaringen over stoornissen/problemen heen te vergelijken (eindtermen 4 en 6);
  • het proces van diagnostiek en hulpverlening aan de hand van de klinische cyclus te beschrijven en de bijbehorende theoretische modellen te kennen voor de eerder genoemde problematiek, waarbij oog is voor overeenkomsten en verschillen over problematieken heen (eindterm 5);
  • voorgenoemde wetenschappelijke theorieën en verklaringen, onderzoeken en orthopedagogische toepassingen te evalueren op sterke en minder sterke (of ronduit zwakke) punten en –op basis hiervan- het geëvalueerde op wetenschappelijke, praktische waarde te beoordelen (eindtermen 6, 11 en 14).

college: Erasmus MC Academie

Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud

De klassieke Oudheid vormt het begin van de Westerse wijsbegeerte; met name de Griekse Oudheid kenmerkt zich door een verbazingwekkende rijkheid aan filosofen en denkbeelden, die ons denken tot op de dag van vandaag op diepgaande wijze hebben beïnvloed. De cursus begint met de eerste Griekse filosofen, nog voor Socrates, en vervolgens zullen diens leven en ideeën worden behandeld binnen de contekst van het Athene van de vijfde eeuw voor Christus. Vervolgens komt de metafysische en de kentheoretische invulling aan bod die Plato gaf aan de erfenis van Socrates, waarna de filosofie van diens leerling Aristoteles wordt behandeld. Daarbij zal aandacht worden besteed aan diens metafysica, kenleer, logica, ethiek en (mogelijk ook) zijn politieke filosofie. De periode vanaf Aristoteles kenmerkt zich door de dramatische historische veranderingen die in gang worden gezet door zijn beroemdste leerling, namelijk Alexander de Grote. Door diens veroveringen breidt de Griekse wereld zich uit over het gehele oostelijke gedeelte van de Middellandse Zee en ver daarbuiten. In de Hellenistische periode daarna ontwikkelen zich de Stoïsche en Epicureïsche scholen, die zich concentreren op logica, een materialistische fysica en vooral een ethiek waarin de afwezigheid van leed als het hoogste goed wordt verdedigd. De cursus wordt afgesloten met het syncretische gedachtengoed van de neoplatonist Plotinus.

De colleges worden niet opgenomen.

 

Leerdoelen Kennis en begrip van de Antieke Wijsbegeerte. Belangrijk om te weten Deelname aan de werkcolleges is toegestaan voor alle studenten; deelname is verplicht voor de voltijders. Voor hen geldt: meer dan één keer afwezig bij een werkcollege zonder toestemming van de Examencommissie = 0,5 punt aftrek van het eindcijfer per verzuimd werkcollege.

text:
Inhoud
Het practicum van dit blok gaat over probleemgestuurd onderwijs en over informatievaardigheden. Hierbij komen enkele vaardigheden aan bod die cruciaal zijn om goed te presteren binnen een wetenschappelijke opleiding en binnen het probleemgestuurd onderwijs.
Leerdoelen
Aan het einde van dit practicum zijn studenten in staat om:
  • de zelfstudie op een kritische, diepgaande manier aan te pakken (eindtermen 8 en 14);
  • de rol als groepslid, gespreksleider en notulist binnen het PGO op goede wijze te vervullen (eindtermen 16, 17, 18 & 19);
en aan de hand van gerichte instructie en begeleiding (onderdeel schrijfonderwijs):
  • pedagogische of onderwijskundige onderzoeksvragen te formuleren (eindterm 9);
  • literatuur te selecteren op relevantie en wetenschappelijke kwaliteit (eindterm 13);
  • verbanden te leggen tussen bronnen, informatie uit verschillende bronnen te integreren en bronnen kritisch te beschouwen (eindterm 13);
  • wetenschappelijke basisliteratuur te vinden bij een specifieke onderzoeksvraag (eindterm 13).

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Pain is an all-too-familiar problem and the most common reason that people see a physician. Pain is an adaptive process and serves an important purpose by alerting us to potential tissue damage and injuries and thereby inducing protective reactions. For a long time, pain was considered as a purely physical sensation and symptom of an underlying somatic disease. In the last decades, it has become clearer and clearer that pain is a psycho-biological experience including sensory and emotional components.  
In this course, students will be introduced to the biological and psychological underpinnings of pain and experimental paradigms to investigate pain in the psychological laboratory. The main focus will be on psychological factors of pain such as the influence of emotions, attention, expectations (placebo-effect). Other topics of this course include phenomena such as phantom limb pain or chronification of pain and their underlying neurocognitive mechanisms. Furthermore, diagnostics of pain and different psychological treatment approaches will be discussed.
  Leerdoelen The aim of this course is to increase students' knowledge of a topic, which has gained increased interest in Clinical Psychology in recent years: Pain and its modulation by psychological factors. The main goal is for students to learn about recent scientific insights into the neurobiological basis and psychological models of pain, its modulation by psychological factors, and (psychological) treatment methods.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie

Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructor: Dr J. Engelberts (EUR)
 
Course description:
Nowadays, even mobile phones and tablets have multiple core central processing units (CPUs), as do have the simplest laptop and desktop PCs. Using their combined compute power, however, is not trivial. This is as true for the small systems, as well as (worlds) largest computer systems. In data science, making use efficiently of all compute power is a required skill that needs to be learned. In this course you will be taught how to have all cores take part in a single task, or to have each core working on its own share of the total task.
Modern day researchers quite often have to rely on larger systems than their own. In the Netherlands many use the national supercomputer clusters, Lisa and Cartesius, at SURFsara. Like most other large shared computer systems in research, these systems have UNIX, or Linux, running as operating system. On top of that, many of them make use of a batch system to give multiple users a fair share of the total resources.
After working with Lisa, the different types of parallel programming will be taught with Python as programming language. Although C and Fortran are very common in high-performance computing, it is also possible to use parallelism in Python, the language of choice for many researchers in the data science field.
The contents of this course comprise a BASH (Unix shell) course, a Python recap, an introduction to Jupyter Notebooks and a programming course to learn how to work with different parallel modules and packages in Python. For the latter, the “Python Parallel Programming Cookbook” is used. Although referred to as a cookbook, it has a decent amount of theory to build a foundation for deeper understanding of parallel paradigms.
 
Leerdoelen

By the end of the course, students will be able to:
 

  • Acquire a theoretical understanding of parallel computer architectures and different parallel paradigms
  • Be able to write and run BASH shell scripts; work with large batch systems (at SURFsara, or anywhere) and write parallel code in Python

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This seminar takes the ubiquity of digital media technologies as a starting point and aims to understand and explain how traditional roles of (media) audiences have changed. Although the Web2.0 enthusiasts are overtly positive about active user roles and applaud the online possibilities of user participation, others approach the activities of users with caution and skepticism. Some critics claim that self-publishing undermines our sense of what is true and what is false and corrupts our culture.

The central topic of this seminar is the reconfiguration of the traditional consumer/producer relationship in the online media domain. Theoretically, the approach is informed by different approaches. The Social Shaping of Technology perspective, the concept of spreadability and Uses and Gratifications theorizing provide prominent and specific interpretative focuses. In class, we will study and critically assess these different theoretical perspectives on participation.

The selection of compulsory literature contains sources that have attained a classical status (e.g., O’Reilly, 2005) and sources covering contemporary theoretical and practical developments. Cases are on purpose chosen from different periods aiming to advance theoretical understanding.

Students are expected to critically engage with the theoretical matter and actively participate in and contribute to an open and inspiring learning environment. Individual engagement is combined with team efforts through mini lectures, and poster presentations. The classroom is partially ‘flipped’ by means of quiz questions supplied on Canvas.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of
  • The value of different theoretical perspectives on (participating) online media users.
  • The value of empirical research on new media users.
  • The ways in which scientific knowledge can be applied to a relevant case study.
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Analyze recent and future trends in new media usage.
  • Reflect critically on the claims made by researchers and theorists from different perspectives.
  • Take and defend different theoretical positions.
  • Independently analyze an empirical case study.

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)

course_title: Parties and Governments in Global Times
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud This course in the Politics & Society specialization focuses on the political relevance of different types of globalization for political parties, governments, and domestic and international policy. First, we focus on the new challenges that political parties face due to globalization. It inspires their reconsideration of actions, strategies, and guiding principles, poses threats to some of these, while it provides opportunities for other ones. Hotly debated topics that will be addressed in this course are questions such as whether globalization explains the rise of new populist parties, whether it leads to fragmentation of the party landscape, and whether it affects party ideologies. Second, contemporary governments have to deal with all abovementioned aspects and political corollaries of globalization. The general question is how governments behave in a globalized context. Governments and their constituting political parties increasingly have to navigate between the often conflicting demands of their constituency and international obligations, such as those stipulated by the European Union (EU). Do they, for instance, pursue a politics of austerity as agreed upon in response to the European financial and debt crises, and consequently reform the welfare state? And how do governments respond to other globalization-related issues, such as immigration and asylum applications? Do governments become less generous? And what role do party ideology, party competition, public opinion, and business interests play in the process?
Third, we discuss the increased impact of supranational organizations like the EU, transnational networks and civil society organizations on citizens and policies. How do citizens perceive the EU and what factors explain the differential support for EU integration across individuals and countries? Moreover, does public opinion and the changing party landscape affect the EU and its institutions as well?


  Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

• Differentiate among the types and aspects of globalization processes taking place;
• Explain social-scientific theories on how globalization influences party systems, party ideologies, and government behavior;
• Explain social-scientific theories on the way in which governments and policies related to global issues are influenced by tensions between domestic politics and international obligations;
• Apply the above-mentioned social-scientific theories on the relationship between globalization and politics to contemporary political phenomena;
• Discuss the similarities and differences between social-scientific theories on the relationship between globalization and politics;
• Critically reflect on social-scientific theories on the relationship between globalization and politics;
• Formulate and test a theoretically informed hypothesis related to the impact of globalization on political institutions
• Orally present the findings of the above-mentioned analysis to an informed audience. Extra Note: We allow up to five elective students. Selection will be based on both prior knowledge and motivation. Note that basic knowledge and affinity quantitative social-scientific methods is needed in order to understand a substantial part of the mandatory literature.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud This course aims to provide students with a thorough understanding of the underlying mechanisms of heart diseases. The students will be able to integrate the information acquired in other disciplines such as Life Support, Human Anatomy, and Human Physiology. The general approach to study the different diseases will include four essential components: cause/aetiology, mechanisms of development (pathogenesis), structural alterations of cells (morphologic changes), and the consequences of changes (clinical manifestations). During this course, students will also learn skills that will help them to structure the acquired knowledge in a clinical context.
  Leerdoelen
The aim of this course is to acquire a basic knowledge of the pathology and pathogenesis of diseases affecting the heart. At the end of this course, you will:
  • have obtained fundamental knowledge about the pathology and pathogenesis of diseases within the domains of cardiology.
  • describe, distinguish and analyze how specific diseases affect the function of the heart, disrupting the homeostasis of the organism (pathophysiology);
  • explain why particular symptoms are presented in patients with these diseases;
  • know how to apply diagnostic tools and clinical skills;
  • distinguish and evaluate the different available therapeutic approaches for the various diseases.

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud In this course, the students will distinguish essential principles in evaluating pulmonary complaints and patients. They will learn to recognize the cause/aetiology, mechanisms of development (pathogenesis), structural alterations of cells (morphologic changes), and the consequences of changes (clinical manifestations) of pulmonary diseases.
  Leerdoelen The aim of this course is to acquire a basic knowledge of the pathology and pathogenesis
of diseases affecting the heart, lungs and kidneys. At the end of the course, you will:
  • Have acquired fundamental knowledge about the pathology and pathogenesis of diseases within the domains of cardiology, nephrology and pulmonology;
  • Understand how specific diseases affects the function of the different organs, disrupting the homeostasis of the organism (pathophysiology);
  • Understand why specific symptoms are presented in patients with these diseases;
  • Know how to apply diagnostic tools and skills;
  • Know the different available therapeutic approaches for the different diseases.

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud This course aims to provide students with the skills and knowledge required to understand the aetiology and pathophysiology of different diseases affecting the kidney. The students will also learn how to perform differential diagnoses, recommend investigations and treatment of patients, and to determine the prognosis of nephrological diseases.

  Leerdoelen
The aim of this course is to acquire a basic knowledge of the pathology and pathogenesis of diseases affecting the kidney. At the end of this course, you will:
  • have obtained fundamental knowledge about the pathology and pathogenesis of diseases within the domains of nephrology.
  • describe, distinguish and analyze how specific diseases affect the function of the kidney, disrupting the homeostasis of the organism (pathophysiology);
  • explain why particular symptoms are presented in patients with these diseases;
  • know how to apply diagnostic tools and clinical skills;
  • distinguish and evaluate the different available therapeutic approaches for the various diseases.

course_title: Pathology & Pathogenesis IV: Nutritional and Gastrointestinal Diseases
college: Erasmus University College
text: Inhoud In this course, we will study the pathology and pathogenesis of a selected set of diseases affecting nutrition and the gastrointestinal tract. Student will expand their knowledge of the physiology of the GI tract, pancreas and liver in health, and they will be able to describe the pathophysiological mechanisms leading to disease. They will recognise gastrointestinal signs and symptoms, gaining practical knowledge on how to treat a patient with GI complaints.

course_title: Pathology & Pathogenesis V: Metabolism and Hormonal Regulation
college: Erasmus University College
text: Inhoud In this course, the students will integrate the knowledge obtained in the previous Pathology and Pathogenesis courses. They will learn about the role of the endocrine system in maintaining homeostasis, and they will be able to describe how the secretion of hormones is regulated, and how disruption of the normal physiology can lead to different diseases. Finally, the students will develop the ability to evaluate, treat and monitor common endocrine disorders, and also familiarise themselves with less common endocrinological afflictions.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['A Bosdijk, MSc', 'dr. HJM Finkenflügel', 'PI Crompvoets, MSc', 'prof.dr. AP Nieboer', 'prof.dr. JM Cramm', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']
text:
Inhoud During the course ‘Patient Centred Care Delivery’ (PCCD) students will be taught the most important theories, systematic reviews and empirical findings regarding PCCD. PCCD has been on the healthcare agenda for decades and has received increased attention. The concept of patient-centredness has grown into an important dimension of high-quality healthcare. Organisations aim to deliver care that is patient-centred in order to improve patient outcomes. In healthcare, increasingly important are the patient’s perspective and involvement, shared decision-making and patient-reported outcomes. The literature advocating patient-centred approaches in healthcare is widespread and research has shown that PCCD can result in improved health, health behaviours, and quality of life of patients and their family/caregivers. However, the evidence remains inconclusive and many organisations and professionals remain unknowledgeable or struggle on how to improve PCCD. During this course we will focus on different dimensions of PCCD and its impact on patient outcomes, innovative solutions (e.g., integrated care programmes), the role of organisations/teams, neighbourhoods and communities, as well as the patient’s context.

Insight into the concept of PCCD will be provided, including different models, theories and definitions. Different innovative approaches to PCCD will be introduced as well as their impact on (patient) outcomes (Theme 1). Attention will be given to various forms of interactions between professionals and patients. We will focus on legal aspects of informed consent and shared decision-making (Theme 2). Behind every professional, there is a team that influences the quality of care delivery to patients. Nowadays, with an astonishing rise of chronically ill patients and patients with multimorbidity, professionals are dealing with patients with complex and multiple needs. These changing needs from acute to chronically ill patients ask for a different approach in care provision.  Interprofessional collaboration is needed to support the needs of these patients, which requires communication and coordination between professionals from various occupational backgrounds and a supportive team climate (Theme 3). In turn, effectiveness of these teams is influenced by the culture, structure and availability of resources within the larger organisation. Also, leadership affects interprofessional collaboration between professionals and in turn quality of care delivery to patients (Theme 4).

In order to create co-care delivery between professionals and patients, diversity in care delivery is needed. Just as professionals operate within a team and organisational context, patients are influenced by their individual/personal environment as well. For example, patients differ in their educational level, their ability to self-manage their well-being, and their way of coping with diseases or illnesses. Special attention will be given to the continuing rise of socioeconomic health inequalities and how culture influences effectiveness of care delivery (Theme 5). Patients are not only influenced by their individual/personal environment, but by the community context as well. The neighbourhood context plays an important role in (improving) healthy lifestyles or fostering active and healthy ageing in the community. We will discuss the role of neighbourhoods and innovative solutions in the community (e.g., community health nurses, collaboration between health, social care and informal networks) on PCCD and patient outcomes (Theme 6).

Language: Workgroups and field trip/session are in Dutch
Leerdoelen
  • Students are able to analyse important theories and conceptual models concerning PCCD
  • Students are able to argue how the organisation of care delivery and interprofessional collaboration contribute to PCCD with the help of theories, models, and instruments from the scientific literature and innovative solutions in healthcare practice.
  • Students are able to assess pros and cons of shared decision-making (SDM) compared to other medical decision-making models.
  • Students are able to discuss transformations in healthcare delivery from acute to chronic care, which result in changing demands, roles and expectations of patients as well as different interactions between professionals and patients and different approaches to the organization of healthcare to improve PCCD.
  • Students are able to defend that diversity in care delivery is needed to improve patient outcomes and enhance PCCD with the help of theories and empirical evidence about the influence of the patients’ context on the effectiveness of care delivery.
  • Students are able to assess the role of neighbourhoods and communities in health (behaviours) and quality of life using different theories and models from the scientific literature and innovative solutions in healthcare practice.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['A Bosdijk, MSc', 'dr. HJM Finkenflügel', 'H Hussein, MSc', 'MV Tietschert', 'PI Crompvoets, MSc', 'prof.dr. AP Nieboer', 'prof.dr. JM Cramm', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']

course_title: Pedagogisch handelen onderdeel: Creëren van een inclusief pedagogisch klimaat
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Bij het creëren van een inclusief pedagogisch klimaat, speelt jouw pedagogisch handelen een belangrijke rol. Je hebt als leerkracht een voorbeeldrol. Je leeft inclusiviteit als het ware voor in de manier waarop jij met de kinderen en de groep omgaat. Je leert in het pedagogisch handelen deel van deze module elementen uit Deep Democracy en groepsdynamica in te zetten om verbondenheid in de groep te creëren. Je leert achtergronden van gedrag van leerlingen te verstaan en te begeleiden zodat een inclusief klimaat ontstaat waarin de acceptatie van iedere leerling centraal staat. Leerdoelen •    Je maakt een begin met het ontwikkelen van onzekerheidstolerantie. Je wordt je bewust van momenten van ‘het niet weten’ en ontdekt wat je dan kan doen (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & indicator 1.2: Handelt met pedagogische tact).
•    Je leert je verder verdiepen in de achtergronden van gedrag van leerlingen in de context van hun leefwereld en leert scherper gewaarworden wat jij zelf in interactie met hen ervaart en meebrengt. (Pedagoog1, 3, 5) (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & Indicator 1.3: & Neemt de leefwerelden van de leerlingen mee in het pedagogisch handelen & Indicator1.5: Baseert het handelen op een pedagogische opdracht).
•    Je maakt kennis met de principes van Deep Democracy en probeert korte werkvormen uit in de praktijk (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat).

course_title: Pedagogisch handelen onderdeel: Eigen opvattingen en impliciete bias
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Aansluitend hierop leer je in deze periode in de pedagogisch handelen lijn om individuele leerlingen en interactieprocessen tussen leerlingen, en de leerlingen en de leraar te observeren en te analyseren. Je leert daarin aanknopingspunten te vinden voor het eigen pedagogisch handelen. Je maakt kennis met theorieën en instrumenten van reflectie. Je leert gedragspatronen te herkennen en je eigen aandeel hierin onderzoeken en maakt daarbij gebruik van de zogenaamde theorie U. Je wordt je bewust van de complexiteit van observaties en van je eigen verwachtingen en impliciete bias. Ook gaan we aan het werk met de Self Determination Theory (SDT). We maken een vertaling naar de praktijk: welke aanknopingspunten vind je in de SDT voor jouw pedagogisch handelen? Het perspectief van de psychologische basisbehoeften gaan je helpen beter af te stemmen op de behoeften van de kinderen. Leerdoelen •    Je kent de Self Determination Theory en kan deze in de praktijk gebruiken als observatiekader en reflectie instrument (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & indicator 1.2: Handelt met pedagogische tact).
•    Je maakt kennis met Theorie U en leert deze te gebruiken als reflectie instrument. Je kent de centrale begrippen uit de theorie en kan deze bij jezelf herkennen en beschrijven (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & indicator 1.2: Handelt met pedagogische tact & indicator 1.4: Fungeert als rolmodel voor de leerlingen).
•    Je leert patronen herkennen in pedagogische situaties, je (h)erkent je eigen aandeel hierin en experimenteert met het doorbreken van patronen en het uitbreiden van je handelingsrepertoire (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat).

course_title: Pedagogisch handelen onderdeel: Leefwerelden en biografie
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud In het pedagogisch handelen onderdeel van deze periode draait het om de vragen: wie ben ik en wie zijn mijn leerlingen? Je onderzoekt je eigen levensloop en waarden en word je bewust van de invloed daarvan op je pedagogisch handelen. Je brengt jezelf mee als je met kinderen werkt, daarom is het goed te weten waar je vandaan komt en wat je belangrijk vindt. Ook verdiep je je in deze periode in de leefwereld van je toekomstige leerlingen. Hoe kun je je, vanuit wie jij bent en wat jij meeneemt, verbinden met de superdiversiteit in de doelgroep waar je mee gaat werken? In de PH-lijn gaan we ook op zoek naar de betekenis hiervan in de dagelijkse onderwijspraktijk. Wat zie je ervan terug in de dagelijkse praktijk op school? En voor welke vragen en dilemma’s staan jij en jouw collega’s op school?  Je schrijft de eerste versie van je pedagogische opdracht. Leerdoelen •    Je ontwikkelt een doorleefd beeld van de leefwereld van jouw toekomstige leerlingen en bent in staat dit te relateren aan jouw pedagogische opdracht (Rol 1: Pedagoog, indicator 1.3: Neemt de leefwerelden van de leerlingen mee in het pedagogisch handelen). 
•    Je leert open en verbonden observeren en gesprekken te voeren. Je bent in staat om bij jezelf waar te nemen wat een geobserveerde situatie met je doet en wat daarvan de pedagogische betekenis is. Hier wordt ook aandacht aan besteedt in de onderzoekslijn (Rol 4: Onderzoeker, Indicator 4.1: Reflecteert en leert op basis van wetenschappelijke inzichten).
•    Je hebt inzicht in jouw eigen achtergrond en biografie en bent je ervan bewust hoe dit jouw pedagogische opdracht en handelen beïnvloedt. (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 4: Fungeert als rolmodel voor de leerlingen & Indicator: 1.5 Baseert het handelen op een pedagogische opdracht).
•    Je bent in staat om het thema diversiteit te analyseren vanuit jouw pedagogische verantwoordelijkheid (Rol 1: Pedagoog, indicator 1.3: Neemt de leefwerelden van de leerlingen mee in het pedagogisch handelen).

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud In de pedagogisch handelen lijn staat tijdens deze module de vraag centraal: Wat is de pedagogische boodschap van de dingen die je doet en zegt? Je leert jouw taalgebruik en gespreksvaardigheid in te zetten om leerlingen te sterken en uit te dagen. Je maakt kennis met de concepten bemoediging en gedifferentieerde feedback (Beate Letschert). En je leert de basisbeginselen van didactisch coachen (Voerman en Faber) als instrument in de begeleiding van leerlingen. Leerdoelen •    Je krijgt zicht op je eigen attitudes rondom lees- en schrijfvaardigheid. (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.3: Neemt de leefwerelden van de leerlingen mee in het pedagogisch handelen & indicator 1.4: fungeert als een rolmodel voor de kinderen).
•    Je maakt kennis met het concept bemoediging van Beate Letschert. Je leert signalen van ontmoediging bij kinderen en volwassen herkennen en weet wat deze mensen nodig hebben. Je kan vanuit het concept bemoediging je pedagogisch handelingsrepertoire uitbreiden en aanpassen op de behoefte van (ontmoedigde) leerlingen en ouders. (Rol1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & 1.2: Handelt met pedagogisch tact & 1.3: Neemt de leefwerelden van de leerlingen mee in het pedagogisch handelen)
•    Je wordt je bewust van de pedagogische betekenis van taal en taalgebruik en verschillende vormen van feedback en gespreksvoering. (Rol: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & 1.2: Handelt met pedagogisch tact & 1.5: Baseert het handelen op een pedagogische opdracht)
•    Je maakt kennis met de principes van didactisch coachen (Rol: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat).

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. FH Wijen', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'S van Loosen', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text:
Inhoud This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:
  • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
  • What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
  • What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
  • How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?
Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed. Leerdoelen A good piece of academic writing gives support for its conclusions. Academic writing is thus argumentative writing: we write to persuade.
In this session, we will
  1. review some of the principles of good argumentation from Module 1.1, and
  2. evaluate and develop the argumentative writing of your draft papers.
We will ask:
  • Is it clear what precisely you want to convince the reader of?
  • What is the support you offer for your conclusions?
  • Is it easy for the reader to reconstruct your argument (for instance, in a diagram)?
  • How can you write more simply and directly?
  • How can you improve your writing process?
We will also do a lot of actual writing, and complete different practical writing exercises that will allow you to advance your paper drafts.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. FH Wijen', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'S van Loosen', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text: Inhoud We will discuss Research Data Management (RDM) as a strategy for your data and research. You will get familiar with RDM processes and the Data Management Plan Template. We will show you examples of how-to fill-in the template and we will have a hands-on session on which you will have time to fill-in and get answers to all your questions about your own Data Management Plan.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Most organizations today collect a wealth of data that could help people management become more evidence-based and impact-driven, and in turn help employees live up to their full potential. However, only few companies manage to use their people data to the benefit of business results. People Analytics could potentially fill this void.

People Analytics constitutes the analytic approach to and statistical analysis of Human Resource (HR) and workforce data to the benefit of employee performance and the organization’s return of investment on human capital. This phenomenon gained traction in recent years, as a movement that could evolve the way we make decisions concerning people-management. It seeks to add value to organizations by leveraging analytical processes, a broad range of statistical techniques, and novel data sources. Moreover, where the returns of investment on human capital have traditionally been considered opaque, People Analytics promises to reveal the bottom line of HR practices, interventions, and investments.

In this course, you learn how People Analytics can be used to improve business outcomes and make better management decisions. Through a sequence of readings, lectures, cases, and experiential exercises, you will learn how to leverage people analytics as a skillset, toolset, and mindset. You will learn what questions to ask, how to determine which methods to use, and how to communicate ideas effectively. This should not only help those who seek to become an HR professional but should help you stand out as a manager and business leader.
  Leerdoelen

Learning Objectives
Upon completion of this course, you should be able to:

  1. Explain the various perspectives on what People Analytics entails and the value it could provide to the organization
  2. Design solutions to issues concerning human capital that build on Human Resource Information Systems (HRIS) and advanced statistical techniques
  3. Critically evaluate ethical and legal issues in People Analytics research and practice
  4. Convince practitioners and scholars of theoretically sound and practical recommendations, drawing from People Analytics

course_title: People on the Move: Global Entanglements, Livelihoods and Intersectionality
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
lecturers: ['dr. SWS Winters', 'dr. Z Kasli', 'prof.dr. AI Chib']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The course consists of 4 different parts.  
 
Part 1: Interview strategy, your story, your aspirations
During the 1st lecture, we will develop the concept of strategy for a job interview and explore one of its key components: how to tell your introduction story.  In the associated homework assignment, you will reflect on your motivations, strengths and personality traits to try & articulate a possible career direction - all of which should be the basis for the other part of the assignment: a first draft of your introduction story.  

Part 2: Tell me about a time when...
In the 2nd lecture, we will explore how to recount in story-like manner your meaningful personal and professional experiences.  In the associated 2nd and 3rd assignments you will develop a portfolio of powerful stories that you can share as you navigate through your job search and the recruitment process.  

Part 3: Networking
In the 3rd lecture, we will explore various high impact tools to help you build your network by connect with unknown people eager to help.  You will learn how to reach out and how to conduct impactful conversations with them so that you can get advice from them and learn about the market and opportunities.  In the associated assignments you will develop a list of target organizations, conduct a networking conversation with a “mentor” and learn how to reach out to strangers to ask for help.

Part 4: Interview strategy (continued)
In the final lecture, we will complete our exploration of interview strategies.  In particular, you will learn about the non-story aspects of job interviews. In the associated assignment you will develop an interview strategy for a potential interview with one of your target employers. Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
What would you say if you could approach the job search process with clarity of purpose, confidence and knowing both how to secure interviews and thrive in them?  The overall objective of this course is to provide you cutting-edge tools and methodologies to:
  1. Find out what makes you uniquely attractive as a job candidate
  2. Decide what you want to do
  3. Build a network of people eager to help you
  4. Learn about the less visible job opportunities
  5. Secure job interviews
  6. Pass interviews
By the end of this course you will be able to:
  • Identify your career-relevant strengths, traits, values and motivations
  • Build and engage professional networks to obtain advice and identify career opportunities
  • Use the art of storytelling to talk about yourself, your past experiences and your professional aspirations in multiple recruiting contexts such as networking and job interviews
  • Develop job interview strategies and execute them

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud For most students, the start of their first year of university is an interesting, but hectic period. Not only will you face new exciting experiences, you may also encounter more demanding responsibilities than before. You are faced with the challenge of choosing a career path and how to develop yourself professionally, as well as the challenge of balancing your new responsibilities with different aspects of your life. To promote the attitudes and skills that help you to become more resilient to life’s demands and to develop yourself in various domains, EUC offers its students the Personal Development Track (PDT). The aim of this track is precisely to help you through the process of self-development.

Open to exchange students: no

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
text:
Inhoud

Course description
 
In this 2-day course you will create awareness about yourself and how to be most effective as a professional in life and work. Time management is often a very difficult aspect of research. How do you prioritize and how do you communicate about that with others, such as your supervisor, colleagues and team members? Whether it is in cooperation or in negotiation or even in conflict situations, it’s good to know yourself and optimize your strengths and be honest about your weaknesses.    

In this training we will work on personal effectiveness, negotiation skills, communication skills, giving and receiving feedback to all colleagues (supervisor, students) and how to plan your daily, weekly, monthly schedules in order to finish your PhD project on time. Therefore, we look at the most effective way of planning your research project and use the rules of project management.    

This practical 2-day course has a pre-assignment and a homework assignment in between (2 weeks) where you work on a few assignments individually and prepare a case together with other participants.    

Learning goals

  • How to prioritize and practice daily, weekly planning.
  • Negotiate and create awareness about the importance of your own goals.
  • Insights in communication styles and how to adapt and connect with others.
  • Conversations and communication skills. Discuss the process with your supervisor. How to give and receive feedback?
  • FeedBack and Communication. Giving feedback to students and colleagues. 
  • Planning, time and project management

Assessments 
Pre-assignment – The Pre-assignment is mandatory for this course  
Participants of this course are required to do a pre-assignment as intake for the course. Please find information about the pre-assignment here.  

This pre-assignment needs to be performed and sent to rosemarie@smitbertens.nl one week prior to the start date of the course. Participants who fail to submit or submit the pre-assignment after the deadline will be excluded from the course. Please note that the cancellation policy will apply. 

Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course This course includes mandatory attendance. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points.
Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, students may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Students should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.
The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.     
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’. 

Evaluation  
Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. We have made the evaluation a mandatory part of the course in order to avoid selection bias in the outcomes, and to make sure every student is heard.    

On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.  

Assignment – The assignments are mandatory for this course 
One week after the end of the course, your assignment, evaluation and attendance will be registered in OSIRIS as PA (=completed), NO (=not completed) or O (=fail). 

No certificates 
Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved. 

Cancellation policy  
Erasmus MC Graduate School charges a cancellation fee of €75 for all cancellations made more than 22 days before the start of the course. Fifty percent of the course fee, with a minimum of €75, is due for cancellations made between 21 and 10 days before the start date. The full course fee is due for cancellations made less than 10 days before the start date, or in case of no-show without cancellation. For Erasmus MC PhD candidates the full course fee in case of the cancellation policy will be the equivalent of the number of course days times €100. All invoices will be sent to the head of department or for external participants to the e-mail address provided upon registration. Those who register for a PhD course agree with these financial conditions.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud This course is about personality disorders and identity problems. First, the distinction between normal personality traits and personality disorders will be examined.

Personality disorders are described in the DSM-V and can be divided into three clusters. The A cluster or ‘eccentric cluster’ consists of the paranoid, schizoid and schizotypal personality disorder. Cluster B or ‘the dramatic cluster’ includes antisocial, borderline, histrionic and narcissistic personality disorder. The C cluster or the ‘anxious cluster’ consists of the avoidant, dependent and obsessive-compulsive personality disorder. This course will be expanding on the clinical picture, diagnosis and treatment of these disorders. Also, dissociative disorders and gender dysphoria will be discussed.

Block assignment: Young Schema Questionnaire
During this course it is important to reflect upon your own (dis)functioning. You will gain more insight and enhance self-reflection by means of completing and interpreting the Young Schema Questionnaire (YSQ). Leerdoelen
At the end of this teaching period, you will have substantial knowledge about the clinical appearance, prevalence, diagnosis and treatment of:

•  paranoid personality disorder
•  schizotypal personality disorder
•  schizotypal personality disorder
•  antisocial personality disorder
•  borderline personality disorder
•  histrionic personality disorder
•  narcissistic personality disorder
•  avoidant personality disorder
•  dependent personality disorder
•  obsessive-compulsive personality disorder
•  personality disorder not otherwise specified
•  gender dysphoria (formerly described as gender identity  disorder)

 Furthermore, you are provided with general knowledge about:
•  the distinction between personality traits and personality disorders
•  themes such as defence mechanisms, transference and countertransference within psychological treatment
•  psycho-diagnostic instruments to determine personality disorders
•  the extent to which personality disorders can be changed
•  various forms of therapy to treat personality disorders and their effectiveness
•  your own (dis) functional schemas and how these influence your view of the world around you (both as a person and as a therapist)
 
Belangrijk om te weten For foreign students, English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials.

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud Today, personality psychology and research into the differences between individuals forms an important fundamental basis for the daily practice of psychologists. Psychologists select people for jobs in corporate life based on personality research. If psychologists treat psychological disorders, they often collect information on a patient’s personality. Personality psychology research is therefore an important basis for every student who wants to work in such diverse fields as clinical research, forensic psychology, or human resource management etc. The course Personality Psychology examines the patterns of thoughts, feelings and behaviour that make a person unique but at the same time similar to others. In doing so, the course provides students with a broad introduction into the major themes that govern Personality Psychology. Leerdoelen At the end of this course:
  • You can define and understand the overarching concepts of personality and individual differences;
  • You have an understanding of and are able to distinguish between the different perspectives on personality;
  • You can explain how key aspects of personality and individual differences contribute to understanding human behaviour;
  • You can apply scientific knowledge of a personality perspective such that you can analyse and solve a small real-world problem that is grounded in individual differences. This means:
    • You will have the basic skills to analyse and clarify a problem brought up by a client;
    • You are able to write a proposal for a client;
    • You can justify your choice of literature/theories and methodology;
    • You are able to apply literature/theories into practice to solve a small real-world problem;
    • You are able to write an advisory report for a client.
