college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
In this course we focus on the topic of personnel recruitment, selection, classification and placement. Theories and techniques are considered for the effective fitting of individual needs, preferences, knowledge, capacities and skills, with the needs and preferences of the organisation. We consider among other things prediction and decision-making models during selection. We also focus on utility models, anti-discrimination models, clinical and statistical prediction and validity generalisation.

Tutorial group meetings take the form of producing the assignments related to the themes above after these have been considered during lectures. Attending the lectures is crucially important for the tutorial groups.
 
Leerdoelen
The goal of this course is to provide the student with a thorough understanding of theory and practice of personnel selection. The purpose of personnel selection is to help identify the most qualified individual for a job. On the one hand, the course focuses on statistical models and theories of prediction, decision-making, fairness, and utility issues in selection. On the other hand, the course is strongly rooted in the practice of personnel selection by dwelling upon best practices in this domain, specifically during the practical.
The course therefore has the following learning objectives:
  • At the end of the course the student is profoundly knowledgeable of theories and the state-of-the-art of personnel selection.
  • At the end of the course the student has an in-depth understanding of statistical models of prediction and decision making in selection, including knotty problems in these domains, including validity generalization, and including state-of-the-art knowledge on the controversy of clinical versus statistical prediction.
  • At the end of the course the student has state-of-the art knowledge of factors influencing the judgement of recruiters and decision makers during selection procedures.
  • At the end of the course the student has a thorough understanding of models of fairness in selection, and has a better developed personal viewpoint on these models.
  • At the end of the course the student can make estimations of utility of selection procedures and of adverse impact of selection procedures.
  • At the end of the course, the student has applied the knowledge in the area of personnel selection by having developed a selection procedure, including some selection devices, and by having used these in the form of a life selection simulation.
Belangrijk om te weten For foreign students, English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials.

Attendance for the lectures and tutorial groups is mandatory.

text:
Inhoud Als professional in de zorgsector zet je je in voor anderen. Om dit op een betrokken en bewuste wijze te doen, is het van belang dat je jezelf goed kent. Met meer inzicht over jezelf en je eigen handelen, maak je namelijk professionele en persoonlijke keuzes die beter bij je passen. De Persoonlijke- en Professionele Ontwikkelingslijn (PPO) helpt te ontdekken hoe je jouw (zelf)kennis het beste in de echte wereld kan toepassen en, als uniek persoon, een verschil kan maken in de zorg.

In het eerste studiejaar ligt de focus van de PPO-lijn vooral op het ontwikkelen van professioneel gedrag. Hierin wordt gefocust op het stimuleren van actieve participatie aan de onderwijsonderdelen en het ontwikkelen van vaardigheden tijdens mentorbijeenkomsten. Dit alles zodat je kunt groeien als student en toekomstige professional.

  Leerdoelen De student kan aan het eind van de Persoonlijke- en Professionele Ontwikkelingslijn:
 
  • een (studie)planning opstellen, studievaardigheidstechnieken toepassen en prioriteiten stellen
  • in een team met elkaar een doel realiseren binnen de beschikbare tijd en met het gewenste eindresultaat,
  • zijn persoonlijkheid duiden inclusief zijn sterke en zwakke punten en hoe dit samenwerking in groepen beïnvloedt,
  • de regels van feedback geven (4G’s) en ontvangen (3B’s) toepassen,
  • een effectieve en visueel aantrekkelijke presentatie geven in het Engels en Nederlands,
  • reflecteren op zijn eigen gedragingen en leerproces m.b.v. het STARR-model,
  • persoonlijke leerdoelen opstellen en terugkijkend op het jaar, reflecteren op het eigen leerproces en SMART doelen stellen voor de studie en professionele toekomst.

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud Sustainability talks have become widespread. The European Green Deal wants to make finance sustainable. The Netherlands promotes sustainable trade. Amsterdam municipality embraced the ‘doughnut model’ in a bid to adopt a more sustainable outlook. The Erasmus Universiteit considers the possibility of its campus going vegan for sustainability reasons. A surge in demand for sustainability has recently materialised at different governance levels. But what does “sustainability” mean and what would its application entail?
The ‘Perspectives on Sustainability’ course will address this type of questions by examining theoretical and practical issues concerning sustainable development. It will do so by adopting a legal and economic viewpoint and showing the various trade-offs involved in decisions pertaining to sustainable development. Leerdoelen The course has four learning objectives:
  • explain the foundations and principles of sustainability by reference to the pertinent scholarship;
  • illustrate the policy and legal framework on sustainability issues by using legal terminology;
  • analyse the theoretical backgrounds of economic theories applicable to sustainability issues by using economics terminology;
  • critically assess a sustainability issue from a legal and economic perspective involving the insights of economic theories and legal rules in their argument

Course description 
To kick-start your PhD, you’ll be informed about Erasmus MC Graduate School and all the possibilities and other topics you need to know about a PhD candidate at Erasmus MC. You’ll receive tips and tricks for a successful PhD and you’ll meet some of the key players in Erasmus MC Graduate School and some of your fellow new PhD candidates.

This session is held every third Tuesday or Friday of the month. Live sessions will be from 09.00-13.00 including lunch, with a maximum of 25 participants per session. Online sessions (once every 3 months) will be from 09.00-12.30, without a maximum number of participants.

Be advised: this session is highly recommended for all PhD candidates within the first 3 months after starting their PhD project. 0.2 EC is rewarded for attendance.

Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course. 
You will receive all details about the location and the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course. 
  

Coffee/tea breaks and lunch are included in the live sessions.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['CA Godoy Junior', 'CA Lopes Pereira, MSc', 'dr. VT Reckers - Droog', 'dr. WF Thielen', 'LGM Bremmers', 'prof.dr. MPMH Rutten - van Molken', 'RJSD Heine, MA', 'YH Chen, MSc']
text:
Inhoud A pharmaceutical pricing strategy is more than simply setting a price to recover R&D investments and adding a mark-up to guarantee a desired profit level. Indeed, a price has often little to no relationship to manufacturing costs in this market. It is the perceived value of a new drug in a broad sense, and how a drug is positioned in the market, that is critical to its success. Especially now that development costs are growing, blockbusters are being displaced by niche drugs, treatment is increasingly personalized, and governments are limiting expenditure on healthcare. For a pharmaceutical company, getting sufficient returns on investments and keeping the pipeline filled becomes increasingly challenging.

Many pharmaceutical companies have shifted their focus from sales and marketing to strategic pricing and market access. This has been accompanied by a shift from a product-centered culture to a disease service-centered culture. Clinicians remain important decision makers, but they must move within the boundaries set by payers. Payers are now the ultimate and most influential clients of the pharmaceutical industry.

The course Pharmaceutical Pricing and Market Access (PPMA) aims to provide students with a detailed understanding of this complex and changing market. We will follow each step of the life cycle of a drug, from phase II clinical trials up to post-launch, integrating both market access theory and examples from the real world. We will discuss the importance of optimizing product launches, real world post marketing studies and innovative pricing agreements. Students will gain insight into how the latest changes in regulations, guidelines and stakeholders in the major EU, US and BRIC countries impact the success of brands, as well as the interactions between all the actors on the markets. They will learn to understand how differences between healthcare systems impact optimizing market access for pharmaceutical products.

Course structure
The course consists of:
  • 12 interactive lectures with plenary discussion (2 lectures of 3 hours each per week)
  • 6 small workgroup meetings (2 hours, once per week) with 10 to 16 students using Problem Based Learning to formulate learning goals, exchange knowledge and have discussions about the case of the week. Problem Based Learning is an active way of learning that gives you better retention of knowledge, enhances your motivation and encourages you to develop skills that are essential for the labour market in the 21st century.
  • 2 meetings in which small groups of (around 3 to 4) students present a business case and debate about the presented market access strategies
Exam
The written examination is 75% of the final grade. The remainder derives from the two presentations on the business cases (10% of the final grade for each business case, a missed presentation will be graded with a “1”) and mandatory attendance of the workgroups (5%, if more than one working group is missed, the attendance grade will be “5.4” instead of a “10”). The presentations of the business cases are scheduled in the third and sixth week and the students’ presence is obligatory. The minimum pass-threshold for the weighted average of the course grade is “5.5”. No reading materials and notes are allowed during the exam, other than an English dictionary. A simple, non-programmable calculator is allowed.

Re-sit
The re-sit is composed of one single written examination that comprises the entire course learning goals and thus counts for 100%. There is no re-sit for of the business case presentations. Leerdoelen By the end of the course students will:
  • Interpret trends and drivers of drug costs.
  • Evaluate how the life cycle of a drug is affected by different aspects of life cycle management.
  • Understand pricing and reimbursement systems of drugs in key international markets.
  • Critically reflect on different stakeholder perspectives on the pharmaceutical industry (e.g. from patients, industry, government).
  • Implement key concepts of pharmaceutical innovation, pricing and market access (e.g. patents, value propositions, value-based pricing, price referencing, market access arrangements) in an own strategy.
  • Develop a pricing and market access strategy for drugs

course_title: Philosophical Anthropology in Times of Crisis
college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud This course explores philosophical anthropology with a view to both introducing it as a philosophical approach, through engaging classical texts of the genre, and opening up the subject to the crises of our own time. As a ‘research program’ in mostly German philosophy from roughly 1920 onward, philosophical anthropology tried to provide a philosophically and scientifically informed answer to the question: what is it to be human? It took inspiration from a patchwork of traditions: transcendental philosophy, philosophy of nature, Lebensphilosophie, and phenomenology, among others. This original formulation of philosophical anthropology also had to relate itself to developments in the philosophy of history, existentialism, and political developments both in theory and in the direct context of the Weimar Republic.
The first aim of the course is to address how philosophical anthropology was constructed and developed in this context. We focus on Max Scheler, Günther Anders, and Helmuth Plessner, the latter’s works serving as a privileged point of access from which all the different threads can be unraveled. The political aspect is considered through the fraught interrelation between Plessner and Carl Schmitt.
The second aim is to evaluate what the role of philosophical anthropology is and can be in the contemporary philosophical landscape and how we should evaluate its importance and prospects. This is considered in relation to its methodology of ‘synthetic philosophy’ and its own philosophical building-blocks. Is such a patchwork still possible? More substantially, we look at potential contributions of philosophical anthropology to ecological questions, philosophy of technology, and social and political philosophy. Because many of the questions involved are still open-ended, this course seeks to contribute to asking these questions in a systematic and more or less unified manner. Students are asked to write a final essay at the conclusion of the course in an attempt to contribute to and/or critique philosophical anthropology as a research program today.
  Leerdoelen After completing this course, students:
  • Have a fundamental understanding of philosophical anthropology and its relation to other philosophical traditions and insights.
  • Can read and comment upon core texts in philosophical anthropology.
  • Can apply the concepts of philosophical anthropology to reflect on contemporary crises in ecology, politics, and other domains.
  • Can critically evaluate philosophical anthropology and its central concepts.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
lecturers: ['dr. CJ Clarke', 'dr. JA Non', 'dr. S Wintein', 'dr. SM Vergara Fernandez']
text:
Inhoud

Issues in the methodology of economics, such as how unrealistic models can (and should) be and how we can appraise their explanatory power, and issues in ethics of economics, such as the goal of economic policy, but also issues of inequality, distributive justice and the moral limits of markets, are discussed in the lectures. In five tutorials, ethical issues in business and in the market are discussed and analyzed. By active engagement with these topics, students develop a stronger moral sense and they familiarize themselves with theoretical frameworks that enable them to form their own considerate opinion.

Leerdoelen

 

ESE Philosophy Course Learning Objectives

 

General learning objectives:

 
  • Students will be able to reconstruct and assess philosophers’ arguments in premise-conclusion form. Students should be able to construct (philosophical) premise-conclusion arguments of their own in essay form. In particular, they should be able to provide reasons for and against the various theories mentioned in the detailed learning objectives below.
  • Students will be able to explain the complexities of various normative concepts studied by philosophers of economics that are relevant in the discussions of economic and social policy. In particular, they should be able to define and distinguish the abstract concepts mentioned in the detailed learning objectives below, including devising examples of their own that illustrate these differences.
  • Students will be able to use these abstract normative concepts in constructing philosophical arguments in essay-form pertaining to concrete settings (poverty, education, healthcare, voting, sweatshops), as explained in the below detailed learning objectives.
  • Students will be able to cooperate with other students in planning, drafting, and revising such an essay.


 

Detailed learning objectives:

 
  • Students should be able to devise examples that help to distinguish the hedonistic, preference satisfaction and Sen and Nussbaum’s capability conceptions of well-being. They should be able to provide reasons for and against each conception in premise-conclusion form. They should be able to explain the different implications of these theories for conceptualizing poverty, for example in debates over absolute versus relative definitions of poverty.
  • Students should be able to distinguish between various conceptions of fairness. Students should be able to formulate Broome’s theory of fairness. Students should be able to explain how goodness and fairness come apart, in particular in the practice of using QALYs to distribute medical resources.
  • Students should be able to narrate the historical background of the equality versus adequacy debate in education. Students should be able to explain the equality versus adequacy as sufficiency distinction in distributive justice. Students should be able to argue for or against an egalitarian or adequacy norm for distributing educational resources and opportunities. Students should be able to assess Debra Satz’s position in the equality versus adequacy debate in education.
  • Students should be able to state the rights-violation, unequal exchange, fair division, and domination theories of exploitation. They should be able to explain how they differ. They should be able to provide reasons for and against each conception, and provide examples of their own devising to support this argument. They should be able to explain the implications of each theory when assessing Powell and Zwolinkski’s argument that sweatshops are not exploitative.
  • Students should be able to define the basic concepts and results (Condorcet paradox, Arrow’s theorem, Gibbard Satterthwaite theorem) of Social Choice Theory. Students should be able to apply various Social Choice functions. Students should be able to explain and apply some prominent axioms for Social Choice functions. Students should be able to explain what, according to William Riker, is the upshot of the basic results of Social Choice Theory for our understanding of democracy.

 

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The course has been entirely redesigned (the topics as well as the learning objectives); as such, the literature has also been changed.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud

As contemporary activist movements challenge western narratives around Colonial exploitation and populist politicians see a nostalgic and nationalist resurgence on the right, contemporary (culture) wars have increasingly come to revolve around history. But what is history? What is, for example, “progress,” what remains of it, and what comes after? And who is the subject of history? The global proletariat, Western Man, or Gaïa? And who, then, is its “object”? Who are the winners of “the process of civilization” and who are its losers?

How do we position ourselves in time? Our understanding of history plays a critical role in our individual and collective self-understanding. From Antiquity to the present, philosophers have therefore offered theories of history, explaining how societies develop and decline. Do they progress or regress, or do they develop in endless cycles, perhaps even in chaotic, non-linear feedback loops? Can history be rationalized at all? In this course, we will investigate what role our understanding of history plays in these social processes. We will focus on the development of a new understanding of history in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries in the work of Kant, Hegel, Marx, and Nietzsche and its critical development by twentieth and twenty-first century philosophers.

While this course module is meant for students in the Philosophy of Social and Behavioral Sciences program, exceptions for students from other disciplines can be made. Please contact the lecturer at kopaitich@esphil.eur.nl.

Leerdoelen After this course, students should grasp, and be able to productively work with, differences and similarities in the understandings of history in philosophy. Additionally, students will comprehend and interrogate the historical self-production of the human in “his” changing social and cultural formations. Finally, students will demonstrate, through writing assignments, their capacity to utilize these concepts in response to historical phenomena/problems in their own discipline. Belangrijk om te weten The full syllabus and all texts will be made available on Canvas two weeks prior to the course. In our first meeting, we will enter into our themes broadly, and have a general discussion about the nature of telling, writing, and thinking about history. Please read the essays below before class so that we can reflect on these topics together and set the ground for our ensuing inquiries.

Week 1 The Actuality of History

-Dipesh Chakrabarty, ‘The Climate of History: Four Theses’, 2009, https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1086/596640
-Lauren Berlant, ‘Thinking about Feeling Historical,’ 2008, https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1755458608000108

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud The lectures and seminar-discussions will focus on the following issues:

1.         The sources of human rights law within the system of public international law.
2.         Human rights as a specific modern discourse: the complementarity of constituting state power and controlling state-power.
3.         Human rights between democracy and the Rule of Law.
4.         Universalism versus relativism.
5.         Facing the limits of autonomy as sovereignty.
7.         Legal, political and ethical skepticism about human rights.
8.         Current human rights questions surrounding globalisation and populism.
 
The teaching method will be inductive and bottom-up: ‘learning by experience’. It means that students will engage in philosophical reflection on human rights issues while studying relevant literature and by presenting and exchanging their findings in the seminar.
The discussions will be introduced, prepared and reviewed by the lecturers (master class method). By doing so, the lecturers will offer the participants a philosophical method aimed at bringing to the surface implicit normative assumptions within a human rights discourse. They will also offer them the means to question these assumptions.
  Leerdoelen The overall aim of this course is to encourage and teach students to reflect critically on human rights and human rights issues, from a theoretical/philosophical perspective. More specifically, after completing the course students should be able to: 
  • understand the history of ideas of human rights and of human rights law
  • understand the difference between legal, political and ethical perspectives on human rights
  • explain the main philosophical challenges of the human rights discourse
  • apply these philosophical challenges to current human rights issues
  • understand and apply the concepts, methods and techniques of philosophical reflection on human rights law as a condition for a decent transnational legal and political order.

course_title: Philosophy of Media: Beyond the Image
college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud
Within the different (inter)disciplines of media- and visual cultural studies there exist a range of approaches to the interpretation and analysis of images and other media contents. Consider for instance semiotics and deconstruction in literary studies, formal and cultural analysis in film studies, iconography and composition in the study of art and quantitative and qualitative discourse analysis in studies of mass media and social media. These approaches share a tendency to “look through” media in order to focus on the image and other visual contents.
The course Philosophy of Media: Beyond the Image invites students to not only look through media as so many windows on the world – but to also take a critical media philosophical look at media in order to conceptualize media as driving forces behind large scale historical changes and a wide range of developments in our contemporary world.
The course is structured around the media philosophical strands of media ecology (both in the various European and Canadian traditions) and media archaeology (in the Nordic tradition) and focuses on the philosophical implications of canonical texts by authors such as Roland Barthes, Walter Benjamin, Marshal McLuhan, Friedrich Kittler, Donna Haraway and N. Katherine Hayles.
In weekly tutorials as well as lectures, film screenings and site visits to media labs, students explore topics such as the relationship between technology and human agency, media as extensions of the human body and the central nervous system, mediacentric historiographies and media archaeologies, as well as the social, cultural and political implications of various media ecologies from the past, present and future.
Leerdoelen After this course, students will be able to:
  • Describe and explain the various histories of the social media platforms and applications under discussion;
  • Understand the basic tenets of the political economic and STS perspectives on Social Media;
  • Critically evaluate the organizational ecologies and business models of the social media platforms and applications under discussion;
  • Critically evaluate the ways in which social practices and social media interfaces are co-constituted;
  • Formulate a personal standpoint concerning the debates about the ‘effects’ of social media in domains such as privacy, creativity, copyright, distraction, sharing and sociability.
  • Write and present a conference research paper.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['C Buijs, MA', 'dr. CISG Lee', 'R Reshef, MA']
text:
Inhoud Course overview
Philosophy of Science offers a foundation to better understand and evaluate science. In the case of Management, that is not easy: our scientific knowledge concerns things you cannot touch or perceive directly, like markets, organisations, and the mind. In addition, Management is an applied science with roots in different fields, such as sociology, psychology and economics, each with their own assumptions and methods. In order to develop an overview and an ability to contextualize the theories that will be offered later in the (pre-)master, students will learn the most important concepts and ways of thinking Philosophy of Science has to offer.

The course consists of two parts. First the students will get familiar with Philosophy of Science in general by following the thoughts and debates of the most important thinkers of the twentieth century. After that we will zoom in on the science of Management. In addition we will consider current debates in which science plays a role and we will address the question how science can be a force for positive change.
  Leerdoelen Learning goals
After completing this course the student is able to:
1. Recognize and apply the main concepts of Philosophy of Science;
2. Critically evaluate arguments concerning important scientific approaches;
3. Interpret the relationship between theories and concepts on the one hand and facts and empirical research on the other;
4. Identify the assumptions of theories in Management and evaluate their validity;
5. Evaluate and discuss the extent to which social sciences have something to say on normative matters.

During this course students work on the following skills: Analytic thinking, logical argumentation, theoretical interpretation, academic integrity and academic writing.
  Belangrijk om te weten Course structure
The course material is presented in weekly modules on Canvas. Students complete each week’s module in their own time. In addition a number of online Q&A session will be offered: in weeks 1, 3 and 5 of the course. Participation in these sessions is voluntary. Questions can also be asked at any time on the discussion boards on Canvas. Halfway through the course there is an essay assignment, and the course ends with a written exam.
  Extra Assessment and examinations
For this course, assessment consists of two parts: an individual essay assignment (50%) and a written exam (50%). The average grade has to be at least 5.5 to pass the course, but in addition a minimum grade of 4.5 has to be obtained for both the essay and the exam.

Students are expected to take individual tests to the best of their own ability, without seeking or accepting the help of others or use resources that are not explicitly allowed.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Course overview
This course not only addresses profound philosophical questions of how scientific research as a human activity may track the truth about ‘organizational reality’ but also has the aim of providing a conceptual apparatus to understand and evaluate the assumptions and truth claims of the many different theories that exist in the field of management. Management is an interdisciplinary field, and therefore harbors different theories that explain management reality using different concepts and relying on very different assumptions. Sometimes theories in management even give incompatible accounts of the same phenomenon. For both researchers and future managers, it is important to be able to make a reasoned choice between the theories that apply to a specific phenomenon. This course seeks to provide students with the conceptual apparatus relevant to choosing between different theoretical perspectives and aims to develop the critical abilities of students to analyze and evaluate theories in management.

  Leerdoelen Learning goals
The principal objective of this course is to equip students for evaluating and choosing between many different theories in the field of management. After this course, students will be able to:
 
  • Describe various philosophical views of the scientific development.
  • Compare the difference between theories and concepts and facts and empirical research.
  • Explain how to establish the validity of non-empirical concepts and theories in social science.
  • Outline the assumptions of theories in management and assess their scientific validity.
  • Evaluate critical argumentation concerning major positions of management science.
  • Assess and discuss the extent to which social science bears on normative issues.
  • Synthesize and analyze the philosophical stand of a given context.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud

Lectures will be recorded.

Tutorials are mandatory for fulltime students.

An answer to the question 'What is Science?’ will be expounded.

This will lead in a natural manner to the analysis of core concepts of science (method, theory, model, confirmation, verification, infirmation, falsification, observation, explanation, experiment, evidence, aims and values of science). Further an introduction to philosophical debates concerning whether science tells us the truth about reality; social components of science; metaphysical presuppositions that make scientific inquiry possible; epistemic uncertainty in times when action is needed (corona pandemic). In two tutor meetings, Excercises will be discussed, designed to understand the texts better. The text of the course consists of Modules written specially for this course.

Leerdoelen If students already completed General Philosophy of Science (taught in 2017 block 1A), they don't have to complete Philosophy of Science (block 1B).

(1) the student acquires the concepts, insights and skills that are involved in understanding philosophical texts about science.
(2) the student acquires the concepts, insights and skills that are involved in making exercises about philosophical texts to test the student’s understanding.
(3) the student acquires the concepts, insights and skills that are involved in writing a short philosophical text about science. Belangrijk om te weten Requirement for Second Degree students: having followed the course Foundations of Philosophy, in the preceding block, because what has been taught in that course will be taken for granted in this course, by professor and tutors.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. F Van De Putte', 'dr. FH Wijen', 'dr. HCK Heilmann', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text:
Inhoud This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:
  • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
  • What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
  • What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
  • How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?
Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed. Leerdoelen This course aims to:
  • Introduce key concepts and problems in the philosophy of science.
  • Develop the capacity of students to critically evaluate concepts and approaches in management science with regards to fundamental problems in the philosophy of science.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. FH Wijen', 'dr. HCK Heilmann', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text: Inhoud We will discuss Research Data Management (RDM) as a strategy for your data and research. You will get familiar with RDM processes and the Data Management Plan Template. We will show you examples of how-to fill-in the template and we will have a hands-on session on which you will have time to fill-in and get answers to all your questions about your own Data Management Plan.

course_title: Philosophy of Science and Philosophy of Medicine
college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud This course is about philosophical problems that emerge from medical research and practice. Scientific knowledge is often understood as the inexorable product of careful observation, which reveals how things really are. Science itself is often presented as having a (i.e. only one) method, which can reveal such truths. Evidence-based medicine is presented as the application of the scientific method to medicine, in which the truth about treatment effectiveness and the accuracy of diagnostic tests is revealed through careful observation.
The course begins by making a rapid historical survey of different philosophical approaches to doing science taken by canonical researchers in medicine, biology, chemistry and physics. This reveals that a great variety of different methods have been employed to produce scientific knowledge. Insights from this survey are used to identify philosophical assumptions embedded in contemporary medical research and practice.
Evidence-based medicine holds empirical observation in especially high regard, downplaying the importance of theoretical speculation. As the historical survey shows, this was not always the case. Evidence based medicine will be presented as a the latest iteration in a centuries old debate about the relationship between theory and observation. Using contemporary philosophical debates about its strengths and weaknesses, evidence-based medicine will be put "on trial"; with some students being asked to argue in its favour, and others against it.
The course then turns its attention to the evaluation of diagnostic tests, especially to the problems that arise when trying to evaluate a test when there is no reference standard to determine disease status. The course will consider if it is even possible to make observations of disease status without theoretical expectations, and, if it is not, how it is that knowledge differs from belief. Leerdoelen This course replaces last year's course 'Human Enhancement'.
  • This course introduces the student to philosophical problems that emerge from medical science and practice.
  • At the end of the course, the student is aware of the great variety of different approaches to scientific research that have been employed by physicists, chemists, biologists and medics historically and today.
  • The student can describe these different approaches using philosophical language; including ontology, epistemology, empiricism, rationalism, theory, observation, deduction, induction, and abduction.
  • The student can outline philosophical positions in the debate on evidence-based medicine, particularly on determining the best methodology to evaluate the effectiveness of treatments.
  • The student can outline philosophical problems associated with the evaluation of diagnostic tests, particularly regarding how to evaluate diagnostic tests when there is no accepted reference standard.
  • Students are able to offer their own views about how to cope with these philosophical problems.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud

This course is part of cluster 2. Environment, Life and Technology

Starting point is Hegel’s dialectics of scientific experience, focussing on two key text: the introduction to the Phenomenology of the Spirit and to Volume I of the Encyclopaedia of the philosophical sciences. Subsequently, we will discuss how this was taken up by later authors (Engels, Bachelard, Heidegger, Lacan, Butler, etc.). Finally, the question is whether these concepts and methods allow us to come to terms with contemporary technoscience, and vice versa: how can contemporary technoscientific developments revivify / reveal the added value of continental methods and approaches?

Leerdoelen (1) At the end of the course, participants will have deepened their understanding of continental approaches to science and technoscience (focussing on dialectics and its impact on dialectical materialism, phenomenology and French psychoanalysis), both in terms of core concepts and in terms of methodology; (2) Participants will be empowered to actively practice philosophy of technoscience today and employ philosophical concepts and methods in contemporary settings; (3) In addition, we will explore options and conditions for fostering interaction, dialogue and critical confrontation between philosophy and technoscience

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud As sessile organisms, plants must be able to interpret and respond to their environment to grow and survive. They also live on a different time scale than animals, and even though their life is highly complex and often surprising, most of it is invisible (or still unknown) to humans. This course will therefore teach you the basics of plant biology, including plant structure and morphology, metabolism, reproduction, genetics, evolution and systematics. The main goal of this course is to remove all vestiges of zoocentrism from your mindset, giving you the tools to appreciate the uniqueness and specificities of the Plant Kingdom. You will be able to (i) distinguish the plants from other life forms, (ii) understand how a plant is structured, and which modifications have evolved to cope with the different terrestrial environments, (iii) describe the different parts of a plant by using appropriate botanical terms, (iv) discover why plants are the life sources for food and oxygen for all organisms on Earth, (v) understand the significance of the diplobiontic life cycle of plants, and (vi) appreciate the intricate biochemical and signalling networks of plants, including those of photosynthesis, hormone action and communication with other plants and organisms. Finally, the students will be introduced to the richness of plant diversity resulting from eons of evolution, and to enter a natural area and distinguish the plants encountered as being either Bryophytes, Pteridophytes, Gymnosperms or Angiosperms. The course will be supported by extra activities, such as a visit to a botanical garden. Leerdoelen
After completing this course, the students will:
  • Be acquainted with the anatomy and the morphology of the different plant organs;
  • Have a fundamental knowledge of the following systems:
            a) Root system;
            b) Aerial system (stem and leaves);
            c) Reproductive system (Flower, fruit and seeds)
  • Be able to recognise and describe the most important plant species for human use.

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud This course highlights the pivotal role of plants on our lives on one side, and the importance of sustainable agriculture in the food production sector on the other side. The first part of the course aims at integrating descriptive knowledge of plant anatomy and morphology with biochemical and genetic mechanisms, in order to study functional processes ranging from seed germination to flowering and fruit set. It also focuses on the study of plant processes - how plants grow, develop and function as they interact with their physical (abiotic) and living (biotic) environments. Based on this acquired knowledge, the second part of the course will focus on agro-ecology and sustainable agriculture in order to give the students an overview about the current systems of plant production and the development of novel sustainable farming systems, from soil management to fertilisation, and from the application of pesticides/herbicides to the use of GMOs. During the course, up-to-date case studies will be presented in order to illustrate how the knowledge of plant ecophysiology and agro-ecology can be a useful tool to cope with increasing environmental and societal issues, such as climate change, food production, sustainable agriculture and environmental pollution.

  Leerdoelen After completing this course, the students will:
1. Be acquainted with the molecular mechanisms and the physiological processes that
shape and regulate plant life. This includes:
- How plants manufacture biological molecules (metabolism):
  • Photosynthesis – light and ‘dark’ reactions.
  • Respiration and lipid metabolism
  • Assimilation of inorganic nutrients (N, P, S)
- How plants acquire and transport inorganic and organic materials for growth:
  • Water balance and transport
  • Solute transport, translocation in the phloem and photosynthates distribution
- How plants grow and develop throughout their lives:
  • Embryogenesis: root and shoot apical meristems
  • Seed dormancy, germination and seedling establishment
  • Vegetative growth: leaf development, shoot branching and architecture, root
system architecture, secondary growth
  • Control of flowering and floral development
  • Signals and signal transduction: hormones and plant development.
  • Tropisms: growth in response to directional stimuli.
  • Plant senescence and plant death
- How plants interact with their external environment:
  • Biotic interactions
  • Abiotic environmental stress
2. Discover what is new in plant physiology.
Like most areas of biology, plant physiology is
experiencing an explosion of new discoveries and new ideas. We will discuss some of the
new topics in plant physiology and why they are considered important.
3. Understand that plant physiology relates to other fields in biology.
Most of you will never
be plant physiologists. For this course to be valuable to you, you must understand how plant
physiology interconnects with agricultural, forestry, environmental science, genetics, the
health sciences, and other fields. Throughout the course, connections between plant
physiology and other areas of knowledge will be emphasized.
4. Focus on how plant physiology will shape the future.
As students, you must consider the
future and your role in it. Plant biotechnology is putting plants to many new uses and
improving them for old ones. Plants can now be used to grow plastics and fuels, to remove
toxic wastes from soils, and to produce vaccines and drugs. Agriculture and forestry practices
have been altered by new crop varieties that resist stress, pathogens, herbicides, and postharvest
losses. These developments in plant biotechnology are derived from knowledge of
plant physiology and plant genetics. As scientists, business people, teachers, consumers,
voters, and parents, you must contribute to intelligent decisions about how plants should be
used to improve the human condition. To prepare you for this, we will discuss the role of
plant physiology in the future throughout the course.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. A Albareda Sanz', 'dr. PK Marks', 'prof.dr.ing. GR Teisman']
text:
Inhoud Governments design and implement policies to solve societal problems. Many regional, national, and supranational authorities create policies through more or less standardized processes of policy design, formalize policies through decision-making procedures, and implement policies through existing or newly established agencies. But often the context in which the policy is designed and implemented is complex and dynamic. If governments do not sufficiently incorporate this complexity in their approach, implementation problems may arise and policy efforts may evaporate without significant results.

When designing public policies, governments often try to reduce complexity by splitting up a problem in separate aspects, which can be individually targeted by specific policy measures. Traditional methods of policy-making are aimed at identifying and understanding the causal relations in a policy field and specify and target specific elements in these causal relations. However, its causal relations are unclear or unpredictable and dynamic, policies may have no effect at all or unexpected, and perhaps even undesired effects.

This course deals with the question of what governments can do in a complex context, what they often do (putting complexity aside), why they continue to do so (policy inertia), and what complexity-recognizing and innovation-seeking entail as alternative approaches. The course brings together two important streams in state-of-the-art public administration research: complex systems thinking and policy innovation.

On the one hand, we discuss the principles of complex social systems and their characteristics (i.e., non-linear, without clear boundaries, and not operated through mechanical cause-effect relationships). We pay attention to questions such as: how can governments deal with complexity and dynamics in their social environment? Which theoretical concepts are helpful in understanding and discussing complexity and dynamics? Students gain insight in the principles of complex adaptive systems and methods of complex system thinking, in which notions such as co-evolution, feedback, and self-organization play an important role.

On the other hand, we pay attention to the need for policy innovations and the conditions under which innovations come about. Students are invited to reflect on the dilemma between the need for stable policies that contribute to legal certainty for citizens and the need for adaptive, innovative policies, that meet the conditions of a vastly changing social context. Policy innovations are needed to bridge the gap between the system world of bureaucracy and the life world of citizens. Many innovations are aimed at improving the interplay between various government organizations and private and semi-private organizations, such as housing corporations or health insurance companies. These collaborations allow for more demand-oriented and integrated modes of working. The ultimate goal is to generate as much public value as possible in these collaborations. That is why in this course we will examine theories of public value and collaborative innovation, including processes of co-production or co-creation between governments and citizens.

These news forms of governance require a form of direction that is more facilitating and stimulating. In that regard, the course also pays attention to meta-governance approaches to address questions such as "how can a government allow social forces to arrive at innovative and effective solutions without completely relinquishing control?" Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, students are able to:
  1. Understand and apply the most important approaches and concepts in complexity theory of the public sector.
  2. Explain the success and failure of policies, policy programs, or public projects from a complexity perspective.
  3. Assess specific cases by making a complexity analysis.
  4. Summarize the importance of innovation in the public sector by considering public value and new forms of collaborative governance such as co-production and co-creation.
  5. Explain approaches to leadership, management and meta-governance in networks and other collaborative processes.
  6. Assess specific policy innovations through public value and collaborative approaches.
  7. Reflect on strengths and weaknesses of the presented approaches.

course_title: Policy Issues in Public Spending on Education, Health and Labour
college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

The course will focus on the functioning of the markets for labor, education and health which typically are non-standard markets with a lot of government intervention. Questions that will be addressed are:

  • What are the main instruments for policy makers to improve the functioning of the markets for labor, education and health and what do we know about the effects?
  • How can the government stimulate optimal investment in human capital or in health capital?
  • What are the returns to investment in human capital at the individual or at the social level?

Guest lecturers will be invited to tell about recent policy issues.

Leerdoelen
  • To gain understanding of the specific types of market failures in the markets for education, labour and health.
  • Understanding the role of the government in these three specific markets and link this role to the theoretical market failures.
  • To learn the types of government failures in the specific markets for education, labour and health.
  • To be able to assess the intended and unintended effects of governmental interventions in markets for education, labour and health using economic theories.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar No changes compared to last year

college: Erasmus MC Academie

course_title: Political Attitudes and Behaviour in Context
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud The second course in the Politics & Society Master specialisation puts citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours in context: it focuses on the various institutional, cultural, and economic conditions relevant for understanding why political attitudes and behaviours differ across regions and change over time. It does so by discussing both classic and recent theories and research in relevant fields, most notably political sociology, political science, and communication science. The main institutional conditions addressed are political institutions, welfare regimes, and national media, as these prove to be crucial for understanding trends and cross-national differences in political trust, public opinion, and voting behaviour. The same goes for the cultural conditions addressed in this course, which most notably include regional and urban cultures, cultural and ethnic diversity, and religion and secularisation. The final part of the course focusses on the role of globalisation – especially its economic ramifications – for political attitudes and behaviour.

Besides providing in-depth insights into the relevance of contextual phenomena for individuals’ political attitudes and behaviour, this course stimulates sensitivity for recognizing unresolved and unexplored research puzzles. To this end, students write a research proposal on how a context condition affects a political attitude or behaviour of their choice. As such, it equips students with key knowledge and skills needed for conducting their research for their Master’s thesis. In addition, it stimulates students to: 1) analyse and critically reflect on the contents and implications of social-scientific theories and research findings; 2) discuss the application of those theories to contemporary social and political phenomena.
 
This course focuses on understanding and explaining the role of context for political attitudes and behaviours; it does not focus on its moral implications, nor on the moral implications of empirical research on that role.



 
 
  Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

1. Indicate context conditions and related theories relevant for changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour;
2. Describe context conditions and related theories relevant for changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour;
3. Apply to contemporary social phenomena context conditions and related theories relevant for changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour;
4. Analyze similarities and differences between theories on context conditions relevant for changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour;
5. Evaluate applications to contemporary social phenomena of context conditions and related theories relevant for changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour;
6. Appraise the work of fellow students;
7. Develop a research proposal in which context conditions and related theories relevant for changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour are applied to contemporary social phenomena.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

This course is an introduction to political economy. The basic premise of this course is that political actors have their own interests and do not automatically pursue the general interest. As a consequence the government cannot be considered as a single benevolent actor as is typically assumed in Public Finance. Instead interactions between different political actors determine the outcome of the political process. We will consider the incentives of politicians, voters, lobbyists, and bureaucrats. We will see how they interact and determine the outcome and efficiency of the political process.
We will use standard mathematical analysis and game-theoretic modeling to analyze the interactions of political actors. Exercises will complement the lecture to give students the opportunity to apply the insights and practice the tools encountered in the lecture.

Leerdoelen

The objective of this course is to be able to use formal arguments and game theoretical models to analyze the incentives of political actors, like voters, political parties and lobbies and analyze political outcomes.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Unfortunately, there is no teaching assistant offering tutorials this year. Tutorial material will need to be covered in self-study.

course_title: Political Economy of Agriculture and Environment
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
lecturers: ['dr. A Visser', 'dr. JF Gerber', 'dr. LH Perez Nino', 'dr. TM Shegro', 'prof.dr. M Arsel', 'prof.dr. SM Borras', 'prof.dr. W Harcourt', 'ZW Brent']

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['bc. A Aly, MSc', 'dr. L Vandenbussche, MSc', 'dr. MMAC van Ostaijen']
text:
Inhoud The theme of this module is the significance and value of democracy in modern politics and administration. That there is such a value inherent to democracy is not self-evident in a world in which crisis- and conflict management and the effective design of policy arrangements seem to demand clear priority. However the democratic process may be organised, there remains a degree of unpredictability in the behaviour and choice of the demos (‘the people’), as history keeps on teaching us.

Within history as well, democracy was never fully accepted. There was always something to criticise, whether this be the lack of competent judgement of the people, the complexity of decision making, the interested self-seeking of the electorate or political parties, short term effect and the degree to which democracy was overwhelmed by media attention and emotion.

At the same time, political thinkers of the past were fascinated by the idea of self-rule; the notion that given an adequate organisational design, such a design might enable human beings to be genuinely autonomous and independent. Important ideas such as sovereignty, power, social contract, and even the idea of administration itself, were developed in this regard, occasionally also in opposition to the ‘plebeian threat’.

Nonetheless, it cannot be denied that in the course of time, gradually and often operating against the tide, a sense of politics and administration appeared whose principle is self-rule and that often stands opposed to a technocratic idea of the political order. In this course the various stages within this development are identified and characterised in relation to current challenges of politics and administration. Different developments in thinking about democracy are discussed and their institutional realisation in administrative practices is explored. This means that not only the basic ideas and mechanisms underlying modern representative democracy are addressed, but also more recent innovations that aim to enlarge representative democracy with institutions for direct citizen participation. Finally, the challenges of democracy beyond the nation-state in the global realm are explored based on a conceptual understanding of the history of democracy. These themes form the basis of the assignments carried out during the biweekly seminars.

The lectures and seminars in this course are fully integrated. The seminars are used to develop basic historical and philosophical skills that enable students to reflect on the contents of the lectures and thereby work towards a fresh understanding of the character of modern democratic politics and the history of the representative state in its current form. Attending the lectures and staying ahead with the course readings is absolutely essential in order to carry out the seminar assignments and prepare for the individual portfolio assignment. Leerdoelen At the end of this module students can:
  • Explain the most important ideas within political philosophy concerning the emergence, development and challenges of modern democratic system
  • Research classical texts in the history of political philosophy;
  • Develop answers to fundamental questions about democracy, both normatively and empirically;
  • Explain topical disussions related to the democratic design of administrative practices in the present-day network society.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud “And what should they know of England who only England know?” (Rudyard Kipling)

Politics is the process by which groups reach and enforce binding decisions. Power is the currency of politics. To survive, political systems need to force their members to do what they would not otherwise have done. Notwithstanding globalization, national political systems are still the main place for the legitimate execution of power. At the same time, nations differ widely in their institutions for political decision-making. This allows for comparison: learning more about other countries, and therewith about your own country, classifying characteristics of political systems, analysing their causes and consequences, predicting and evaluating the effects of societal and political-institutional change.

This course introduces students to the discipline of empirical political science. After having discussed the main concepts, we will compare and analyse various facets of national political systems. Democratic versus authoritarian systems, political trust, political communication and media, political cleavages, political parties, election rules and voting behavior, parliamentarian versus presidential governments, the structure and function of parliaments, and the role of constitutions and constitutional courts. Looking through the glasses of a political scientist, we seek to answer questions such as the following: Does trust in governments decline and what factors account for trust/distrust? What is the impact of social media on politics? Does globalization lead to new cleavages in society? What factors explain the rise of populist parties? How are governments formed? Are coalition governments less stable than single-party governments? Are parliaments willing and able to control governments and are they representative of the electorate? Leerdoelen After passing the course, students are able to

• define major political science concepts
• reproduce major political characteristics of the Netherlands and a selected number of other political systems
• compare major political characteristics of the Netherlands and a selected number of other political systems along relevant dimensions
• explain causal theories about relationships between characteristics of political systems
• evaluate the validity of causal theories based on existing data
• predict the effect of societal and institutional changes on political phenomena
• evaluate proposals for institutional change based on expected effects on relevant feature of political systems
• develop and defend a position of a political group for negotiating a new constitution
  Belangrijk om te weten This course has a different format than the first year courses. For instance, the tutorials entail debates and a simulation. A series of graded assignments have to be carried out. In combination with the practical you may have three assignment deadlines. Also, from the first day on we will work intensively with the mandatory literature. A few copies of the relevant book are available at the study landscape, but we strongly advise to buy the book in advance and to have the book and the other mandatory literature at hand during the lectures and the tutorials.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud And what should they know of England who only England know?”
(Rudyard Kipling)

Politics is the process by which groups reach and enforce binding decisions. Power is the currency of politics. To survive, political systems need to force their members to do what they would not otherwise have done. Notwithstanding globalization, national political systems are still the main place for the legitimate execution of power. At the same time, nations differ widely in the institutions through which this power is wielded. This allows for comparison: learning more about other countries, and therewith about your own country, classifying characteristics of political systems, analysing their causes and consequences, and predicting the effects of societal and political-institutional change.

This course introduces students to the discipline of empirical political science. After having discussed the main concepts, we will compare and analyse various facets of national political systems. Democratic versus authoritarian systems, liberal versus illiberal democracies, political trust, political communication and media, political cleavages, political parties, election rules and voting behavior, parliamentarian versus presidential governments, the structure and function of parliaments, subnational governments and the role of constitutions and constitutional courts. Looking through the glasses of a political scientist, we seek to answer questions such as the following: Does trust in governments decline and what factors account for trust/distrust? What is the impact of social media on politics? Does globalization lead to new cleavages in society? What factors explain the rise of populist parties? How are governments formed? Are coalition governments less stable than single-party governments? Are parliaments willing and able to control governments and are they representative of the electorate? Why have some countries federal systems and other unitary systems? Leerdoelen After passing the course, students are able to:  
  • Define major political science concepts;  
  • Reproduce the major political characteristics of the Netherlands and other political systems;  
  • Compare major political characteristics along relevant dimensions; 
  • Explain causal theories about relationships between characteristics of political systems; 
  • Identify the effect of societal, political, and institutional changes on political phenomena.

course_title: Politics of Global Development: Debating Liberal Internationalism
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Migration and diversity are key political topics of our time. This course focuses both on the role that migration and diversity play in politics and policies and vice versa. To what extent are contemporary political debates on migration and diversity really new? What role do different levels of governance have in the fields of migration and diversity? What about the role of minorities in representational democracies?
This course focuses not only on contemporary politics and policymaking, but also on how migration and diversity have evolved as topics in politics and governance across and beyond Europe. It provides an overview of citizenship models and, related to these models, different types of migration, inclusion and diversity policies. Furthermore, the course introduces students to contemporary conceptual debates on the management of different types of migration flows as well as to the different scales and levels of migration policies, from local, national, regional to the global. Finally, the course unpacks politicization of migration with due attention to its manifestation in party politics, political movements and media.

  Leerdoelen This course enables students to:

1. Identify the links between political structures, migration and diversity policies
2. Discuss theoretical models of migration, integration and diversity management in the face of new political developments and/or mobility practices
3. Compare migration and diversity policies at different levels (local, national, regional, global) in specific cases
4. Critically examine categories of policymaking and statistical evidence in migration policymaking
5. Analyze the role of politicization and conflict in the governance of migration and diversity
6. Apply existing theoretical concepts and frameworks to current events

course_title: Politics of Modern Development - Decolonizing Power
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud
Public governance, understood as the formal and informal arrangements that determine how  public decisions are made and how public actions are carried out, is an intensely political process that is becoming increasingly complex. Today, the most prominent political unit still is the state, having exercised sovereignty over public policies for more than a century, but whose power, capacity and legitimacy are increasingly challenged by a variety of sub-national and non-state actors.
 
Traditionally approached from a state-centric perspective, public policy is no longer exclusively made by national bureaucracies as an ever increasingly complex web of actors and stakeholders become involved. How such actors are involved in aspects of public policy-making such as agenda-setting, policy formulation and advocacy is therefore a core component of the course.

This course engages with concrete governance problems encountered across the world, such as inequality in cities, corruption and the climate crisis. In doing so, the course will also highlight the role of non-state actors in the policy process, and how governance is evolving.
 
Assessment consist of a group project in which you will produce policy advice on an issue of your choice. Adopting a practitioner’s perspective, you will translate scientific evidence into practical recommendations. In doing so, you will develop basic policy writing and analysis skills which will be of value in a wide range of careers. Leerdoelen On successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
  • Reflect on the current role and place of government in modern societies and describe their historical developments
  • Describe the role of a selected number of political institutions in modern states and reflect on their infuence and performance
  • Describe how governments design and implement policies
  • Reflect on the origins and backgrounds of governmental policies in various policy domains

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Complex governance processes in networks are constantly influenced by the outside world. This is especially happening through the media attention and the dynamics this generates in networks. Media have become a separate institution with its own logic (the media logic) and its own rules how to bring news and package it. Media logic is concerned with the content of the news provided as well as the formats in which news is created and processed. The format of an item on the television news bulletin for instance, has to meet certain criteria: the slot allocated for the story is only a few minutes long, it has to have news value and it should attract or keep the attention of the viewers. These criteria influence how reality is constructed in the news story.
 
Many authors claim that media have profound influence on our daily social life, how policy problems are shaped and on various other institutions in society. And this becomes visible when media pay attention to governance processes. Not only does the visibility of these processes enhance but also the decision dynamics change considerably as agenda forming theories have been arguing for some time.
The mediatized world asks for public leaders who can communicate their messages in clear “sound bites,” who can adapt swiftly to new developments and “media hypes,” and who can create attractive brands which arouse positive associations with citizens and voters. But in this public leaders in modern network society are faced with a growing gap between the front stage of a mediatized political world on the one hand and the daily practical life of complexity of governance processes in networks on the other hand (the backstage).
 
In this course we explore the media as a separate institution, their influence on policy processes and the requirements it posed on public managers. But we also explore managerial strategies that public managers have to influence media attention, like (political) public relations, and public branding. Leerdoelen The goal of the course deals with
  • Being able to explain the most important theories on mass communication and the functioning of the media, also in relation to branding
  • Explaining what relevant developments are in the relation between media, public administration and society
  • Analyzing different aspects of these developments by using concrete examples.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Politieke communicatie bestudeert de communicatie tussen burgers, media en politieke actoren zoal politici en politieke partijen. In deze cursus worden deze actoren geanalyseerd: welke communicatiestrategieën gebruiken politici en partijen, hoe berichten journalisten over politieke kwesties en welke betekenis hebben deze processen voor burgers en de democratie? Studenten analyseren literatuur over politieke communicatie en reflecteren aan de hand van praktijkvoorbeelden op die literatuur. Door middel van kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethoden bestuderen zij een hedendaags vraagstuk op het terrein van politieke communicatie. In deze cursus zal de vraag centraal staan hoe populistische politici proberen een publiek aan zich te binden en hoe het publiek op deze politici reageert. Studenten formuleren op dit terrein een onderzoeksopzet en voeren dit onderzoek tijdens de tweede helft van de module uit.

  Leerdoelen

course_title: Popular Music: Greatest Hits and Critics
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In this course, theoretical and practical knowledge on contemporary popular music production, distribution and consumption is combined to offer students cutting-edge insights into the popular music landscape. In a series of small-scale, interactive seminars, a number of invited speakers from popular music research and/or the popular music profession will share their knowledge on topics as diverse as: music as a technology of the sexual self; streaming and recommendation systems/algorithms; and copyright legislation in the digital era; ‘making it’ as an underground, DIY-label. Students are expected to prepare well for each session and provide input for discussion with our guests. For assessment, students will prepare a session of their choice and write a final paper individually. Leerdoelen

This course is exclusively for students enrolled in the minor ‘MU$IC: The economy, sociology, and practice of popular music’. In this course, theoretical and practical knowledge on contemporary popular music production, distribution and consumption is combined to offer students cutting-edge insights into the popular music landscape.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Popular music has transformed the world. Its rhythms have influenced how we walk down the street, how we face ourselves in the mirror, and how we handle our daily conversations and encounters. It has shaped our morals and social mores; it has transformed our attitudes towards race and gender, religion and politics. (Doggett, 2015)

On the one hand, students are invited to theoretically engage in the critical and systematic study of popular music’s role in societies from its beginnings in youth cultures to its contemporary position in 21st Century digital landscapes. Important key concepts such as genre, scene, (diaspora) identity formation, authentication processes, social and symbolic boundaries, counter- and subcultures and social inequality will be fundamental in this approach. Central to this perspective is to treat popular music beyond its value as entertainment and demonstrate what is sociological about music.

On the other hand, a more practical industry approach will make students familiar with the functioning of the global music industry. First, students will discuss popular music law, regulation and technology – particularly in a time of rampant illegal downloading/streaming and DIY music production. Second, industry and organizational structures are discussed in combination with – third – artistic career development. Leerdoelen In this course, students are given the opportunity to focus on a specific cultural product that plays a fundamental role in everyday life since the early 20th Century: popular music. The topic is approached from two distinct approaches: society (sociology/history) and industry (management/economy). The course aims to familiarize students with the importance of popular music in everyday life and the cultural industries, and provide a toolkit for both critical thinking on and working in/with popular music.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
