Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. I Fragkos', 'dr. K Papalamprou', 'dr. M Tekin', 'dr. T Kucukyilmaz']
text:
Inhoud

This course focuses on the further development of applied analytical skills. The emphasis is on solving specific business problems in a structured way. It starts with formalizing the problem in terms of decisions to be made, constraints and objective function. Then, step-wise procedures and optimization techniques are used to find feasible, high-quality solutions to the problem. Finally, these solutions need to be presented and interpreted properly. This course builds upon courses like quantitative decision making and Supply Chain Management.

Prescriptive analytics is about making informed decisions to solve business problems using data and mathematical models. Prescriptive analytics leads to improved decision making, which also helps at improving the performance of organizations. The course content revolves around one key question: how can we make better decisions and improve performance indicators like cost and efficiency by using the available data and information?

Throughout the course, we provide skills necessary to answer this question via examples from various domains. The course starts with how to translate a business problem into an optimization problem. Key concepts of optimization problems, such as decision variables, constraints and identifying an objective are discussed. Then we proceed to solving these optimization problems, meaning establishing a process that is able to find high-quality solutions. This can be done using algorithms (step-wise procedures) and optimization techniques. Throughout the course, we illustrate how to develop and implement such algorithms by overviewing some focal applications. These algorithms require data and information as inputs and often need to be reliable in highly uncertain environments.
The theory for this course will be provided via short online videos. There will be weekly Q&A sessions to discuss questions about these videos and the assignments. Next to that, tutorial videos will be made available on how to implement the theory on real problems by using programming languages (Python).

The course consists of multiple assignments and/or quizzes on which students work individually and in groups. Support on these assignments is provided with weekly tutorial workshops, where the students can work on their assignments and ask questions.

Leerdoelen After following this course, the students are able to:
  • Translate a business problem into an optimization problem, formulated in terms of decisions to be made, constraints, objective function and required data.
  • Incorporate uncertainty into the analysis.
  • Think algorithmically. That is to formulate stepwise procedures to find feasible, high-quality solutions.
  • Apply these procedures using programming skills.
  • Translate the outcomes of the optimization problem to provide advice for solving the real business problem.
  • Critically reflect on the outcomes of the algorithms, their implications and limitations.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Session One (whole group):
  • Introductions
  • Feedback exchange
  • Managing nervousness
  • Body parts (including voice)
  • Getting their attention
  • Introducing yourself
  • Using the stage
  • Leveraging interaction
  • Managing Q&A
  • Managing hostility
  • What if something goes wrong?
  • Establishing credibility
  • When are you ‘on’?
  • Female and cross cultural things
  • Presenting academic research
  • Those first few moments
  • What if you don’t have an answer?
  • Conferences and networking
  • Video-taped presentation (+/- 5 minutes per person) + facilitated group feedback debrief
  • View and privately discuss video 1:1 with facilitator for further feedback
  • Goal-setting and action-planning
Session Two (1:1 meeting):
  • Private virtual consultation 1:1 with facilitator
  • Possible Zoom recording of a presentation or self-introduction - recording will be sent to the student 
  • Goal setting
Session Three (whole group):
  • Video-taped presentation (+/- 10 minutes per person) + facilitated group feedback debrief
  • Private consultation 1:1 with facilitator rotated with viewing own video and reflection/goal setting
  • Goal setting and sharing
  • Group discussion on how to support each other moving forward
In connection with the highly individual approach, 100% attendance and serious preparation for each session is required. The course is offered three times per academic year. Maximum number of participants is 10. Leerdoelen
  • Clarify what your current presentation strengths and development areas are
  • Understand what presentation techniques are received most positively by audiences
  • Learn what behaviors to avoid when presenting
  • Learn to effectively interact and engage your audience
  • Learn how to deliver your message clearly and concisely
  • Learn how to present to large groups at conferences successfully

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. FH Wijen', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text:
Leerdoelen

In this session you will learn how to (further) develop the front end of your research paper-in-progress. The four modules of this session will centre around the structure and contents of your abstract, introduction, literature review, and theory development. In short, everything preceding your empirical study will be discussed in depth. Getting your paper's front end right is challenging but surely doable and critical to the success of the entire paper.

Prior to the session you will peruse relevant literature and submit your paper's front end, on which you will get personalized feedback. During the session we will have plenary and break-out discussions on each element of a paper's front end.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. FH Wijen', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text: Inhoud We will discuss Research Data Management (RDM) as a strategy for your data and research. You will get familiar with RDM processes and the Data Management Plan Template. We will show you examples of how-to fill-in the template and we will have a hands-on session on which you will have time to fill-in and get answers to all your questions about your own Data Management Plan.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
Accounting is the language of business. Given that the role profile of financial managers has broadened substantially in recent years with a particular emphasis on management skills, accounting and financial management graduates from our programme more than ever need to be able to communicate the key implications of this (sometimes complicated) language to a variety of different audiences in a convincing and easy manner.

Therefore, the department of Accounting and Control offers this 1 ECTS course to provide students with the necessary tools for preparing a good presentation and communicating its key messages effectively. It is mandatory for all incoming students in accounting and financial management.

The course format will be multiple sessions with experienced coaches from the J-building and companies. To pass this course, students will need to attend the sessions. An alternative assessment format will be to prepare a presentation on a subject recorded on video
 
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
Students in this course will learn:
  • How to prepare a clear presentation structure
  • How to create quality slides for different areas and audiences, such as research, real life cases, or executive summaries
  • How to make impact on the audience
  • How to present themselves effectively

college: Erasmus School of Economics
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
text:
Leerdoelen

Course description 
The format of this course is 3 half-day sessions, during which several aspects of presenting will be highlighted. Participants will present multiple times, to watch themselves grow. A mandatory pre-assignment needs to be sent in at least 1 week in advance, so that wishes and expectations for the program can be anticipated. This will allow for customization of each training.  Although pitching and presenting are not the same thing, pitching will also be addressed during the course, as PhD candidates deal with this a lot. On the third day a fellow scientist will be present to watch and give feedback, as it is important that the practice of science is part of this training. In this way, practice and theory will coincide as much as possible. 

The focus of the three meetings will be on: 

- Define your purpose  
- How to make science interesting to listen to and to watch  
- Think about who your target audience is and what is important to them  
- Determine what you want to get across  
- Determine the necessity of your story and work with it  
- With preparation and structure, you do yourself a lot of favors and thus also your audience  
- Learn to see and watch to be able to respond to your audience. What do you see and what do you interpret? 

Be sure to register at least 3 weeks before to the start of the course. You will receive all details about the location and the final program for the course 1 week before to the start of the course. 

Learning goals  

During this course, participants will: 

- Learn what is needed for preparing and delivering a scientific presentation 
- Become aware of themselves as a presenter and research what suits them best to come across well 
- Discover more their own style and gather tools on how to develop this 
- Understand the need and motivation to tune into the target group and translate their interests into their own story 
- Apply and try out the material provided during and outside the lessons 
- Learn to know what you see and give targeted and tailored feedback, for colleagues to improve and to learn from themselves

Mw. Kathinka Fortuin 

Prior to day 3 

Assignment 3:  

  • Prepare a final presentation of max 10 minutes. Indicate your goals and target group. 

Participants 

Day 3: 2-hour session 

  • Presentations 

  • Feedback 

  • Take stock of what learned 

Mw. Kathinka Fortuin 

 

*the program may be subject to change. 


Assessments
Assignments - The assignments are mandatory for this course 
 
Pre-Assignment - Be sure to submit the pre-assignment at least one week prior to the course. Failing to do so will result in exclusion from the course. Please note that the cancellation policy will then apply. 
 
Assignment 1 - Course preparation prior to course day 1: 

  • Read the syllabus 

  • Watch the short YouTube videos  

Assignment 2 - prior to course day 2: 

  • Prepare a pitch, a 2-minute presentation using the structure in the syllabus. Bring your preparation sheet so it can be used for feedback. 

  •  Watch YouTube pitches 

Assignment 3 – prior to course day 3: 

  • Prepare a final presentation of max 10 minutes. Indicate your goals and target group. 

One week after the end of the course, your assignments, evaluation, and attendance will be registered in OSIRIS as PA (=completed), NO (=not completed) or O (=fail). 

Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course 
This course includes mandatory attendance. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points.
Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, students may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Students should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.
The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.     
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’. 

Evaluation  
Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years.  
Shortly after the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.  

No certificates 
Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved. 

Cancellation policy  
Erasmus MC Graduate School charges a cancellation fee of €75 for all cancellations made more than 22 days before the start of the course. Fifty percent of the course fee, with a minimum of €75, is due for cancellations made between 21 and 10 days before the start date. The full course fee is due for cancellations made less than 10 days before the start date, or in case of no-show without cancellation. For Erasmus MC PhD candidates the full course fee in case of the cancellation policy will be the equivalent of the number of course days times €100. All invoices will be sent to the head of department or for external participants to the e-mail address provided upon registration. Those who register for a PhD course agree with these financial conditions.

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud
<html>
<head>
	<title></title>
	<style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
	</style>
</head>
<body>‘Preventie en bestraffing’ gaat over de verschillende manieren waarop we reageren op criminaliteit. Het gaat dan in de eerste plaats om straf. Straf is niet alleen een reactie achteraf, maar de dreiging van straf dient ook om criminaliteit te voorkomen. We bespreken in dit vak uitgebreid het onderzoek naar de effectiviteit van verschillende vormen van preventie van criminaliteit, zowel door straf, als door sociale en situationele interventies. We kijken ook naar ontwikkelingen in het bestraffingsbeleid, in historisch en internationaal perspectief. Hoe soft of streng is Nederland in vergelijking tot andere landen en hoe heeft het Nederlandse sanctiebeleid zich ontwikkeld in de afgelopen 30 jaar? Deze ontwikkelingen worden geduid met behulp van het begrip beheerscultuur.</body>
</html>

Leerdoelen
<html>
<head>
	<title></title>
	<style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
	</style>
</head>
<body>In dit vak zullen jullie kennis opdoen van de verschillende strafdoelen, hun onderlinge relatie en de mate waarin zij in het huidige sanctiebeleid tot uitdrukking komen. Tevens biedt dit vak inzicht in de doelstellingen en effectiviteit van verschillende resocialiserende interventies en andere mogelijkheden tot preventie van criminaliteit, met als doel voor verschillende criminaliteitsproblemen aanbevelingen te kunnen doen voor effectieve interventies, en kritisch te kunnen reflecteren op de waarde van effectiviteitsonderzoek van interventies. Voorts zullen jullie in dit vak leren om de ontwikkelingen in het Nederlandse sanctiebeleid in een historisch kader en internationaal vergelijkend perspectief te plaatsen. Daarnaast kunnen jullie, na afloop van het vak, de huidige verhouding tussen dader, slachtoffers en maatschappij verklaren aan de hand van het begrip beheerscultuur. Dit biedt het kader om diverse aspecten van het huidige sanctiebeleid met elkaar in verband te brengen en de maatschappelijke consequenties ervan te kunnen doorgronden.</body>
</html>

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
Pricing approaches have evolved from very restrained economic and financial perspectives to a broader consumer-oriented framework. In this course, we will study different approaches to have a comprehensive understanding of the economic, strategic, and behavioral considerations that impact a pricing strategy. We will study theoretical concepts linked to economic and behavioral approaches to pricing, price customization/discrimination, price bundling and multi-part tariffs, value-based pricing, dynamic pricing, retail pricing strategies, pricing for goods/services with externalities, and pricing in two-sided markets. We will use examples and case studies from various product categories such as consumer packaged goods, financial services, healthcare plans, and cell phone plans.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • Understand the economic and financial aspects of pricing: estimate the demand curve, estimate customer willingness-to-pay, and calculate profit-maximizing prices.
  • Develop a value-based pricing strategy that also considers the effect of non-price factors on perceived value.
  • Learn to spot all relevant aspects of pricing in the marketplace, through business applications, examples and case studies.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. J de Vries', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']
text:
Inhoud
Onderwerp
Primaire processen omvatten de product- of diensten-voortbrengende processen, waarmee bedrijven hun geld verdienen. Activiteiten die hierbij ondersteunend zijn (informatiemanagement, financieel management, personeelsmanagement en dergelijke), worden aangeduid als secundaire processen. Primaire processen in organisaties omvatten het inkoop-, productie-, verkoop, distributie-, service- en retourverwerkingsproces. In dit college wordt ook de ontwikkeling van productieprocessen tot de primaire processen gerekend. Het geheel van aan elkaar gerelateerde activiteiten behorende tot het product- of dienstcreatie en -realisatieproces noemt men in het Engels Operations Management. Voor industriële ondernemingen omvat dit aspecten als mechanisering en automatisering inclusief de bijbehorende informatietechnologie, logistiek, maar ook capaciteitsplanning en layout. Alle functies in een onderneming - van Research tot Marketing - hebben direct of indirect relaties met de voortbrengende processen. De aandacht van het vak is zowel gericht op industriële als op diensten-voortbrengende ondernemingen.
Relevantie
Elke organisatie heeft primaire en secundaire processen. In de primaire processen wordt toegevoegde waarde van het product of dienst gecreëerd. In de automobielindustrie bestaan de primaire processen uit het ontwikkelen en productierijp maken van nieuwe modellen en features, het efficiënt inkopen en assembleren van ingekochte componenten, zorgen voor efficiënte aan- en afvoerlogistiek, het vinden van de juiste afzetkanalen, het collecteren, demonteren en herverwerken van auto's aan het eind van hun levensloop. Bij een bedrijf als McDonald's bestaat het primaire proces uit het ontwikkelen van nieuwe producten, het vinden van goede leveranciers (wereldwijd), aan- en afvoerlogistiek van leveranciers naar de verschillende distributiecentra, fabrieken en restaurants, het productie- en verkoopproces in het restaurant en de recycling van het afval dat overal wordt gegenereerd. Het is duidelijk dat de primaire processen van dergelijke organisaties veel verschillen vertonen. Er zijn echter ook overeenkomsten.
  Leerdoelen

Leerdoelen

na afronding van het vak is de student in staat om:
  • De relatie tussen verschillende proceseigenschappen en prestatiemaatstaven te begrijpen
  • De eigenschappen van prestatieanalyse, procesontwerp, en planning te begrijpen
  • Kwantitatieve problemen op het gebied van prestatieanalyse, procesontwerp en planning op te lossen
  • De implicaties van de uitkomsten van kwantitatieve problemen te evalueren

course_title: Principles of Ecology: Biodiversity & Nature-Inclusive Design
college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud This course provides a background in the fundamental principles of ecology, including concepts of population sampling, population dynamics, community interactions and ecological succession. Students will acquire an "ecological literacy" about how the natural world works, and develop an understanding of how scientific methods are used to construct ecological knowledge. The course will also explore the issue of biodiversity loss as one of today's major ecological challenges, and the importance of research on nature-inclusive design to address these concerns. This course is aimed at giving students an overview of the field of ecology and how it applies to the sustainability of human societies. If you are curious about how we can address the major challenge of biodiversity loss, this course will provide you with a good introduction to the nested complexity of the natural world and to the use of design to include nature in our surroundings. Leerdoelen
After completing this course, you will be able to:
  • analyse how biotic and abiotic interactions give rise to patterns of abundance and distribution of organisms at several scales;
  • design a management plan for the conservation of biodiversity in a world region by assessing the conflicts and opportunities on the use of natural resources by local populations.
  • apply ecological principles to current environmental challenges and conservation concerns;
  • characterize patterns and processes in nature through direct experience with local ecosystems;
  • assess the effects of human disturbance on ecosystems through ecological succession and alternative-stable states theory;
  • use ecological models to illustrate the abundance of organisms and the dynamics of populations over time;
  • compare structural and functional features between different types of ecosystems;

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud

Does Okun’s law hold in practice? Does the Phillips curve really exist? In this course you will learn how to perform empirical analyses to answer this kind of questions. The course is strongly build upon what you have learnt in Basic Statistics and Intermediate Statistics I and is specifically aimed at students with a major in economics. During the course we will discuss important concepts for time series such as stationarity, unit roots and autoregressive models. Moreover, you will learn how to perform the analyses in the software program Stata.

Leerdoelen After succesful completion of this course, you:
  • Understand the main concepts related to simple and multiple regression;
  • Are aware of common techniques and concepts for time series analysis;
  • Are able to apply ordinary least squares;
  • Can perform basic analyses in Stata and are able to interpret Stata output;
  • Can formulate a research question and testable research hypotheses on the basis of previous research and economic reasoning;
  • Can apply statistical methods to answer a research question;
  • Are able to structure and discuss the research findings through a written report.

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
This course lays the groundwork for financial modeling in Market-and Bank-Based Financial Markets. As such, the course is a building block for later the electives FinTech and Algorithms in control. We start by discussing sources of company financial information, how different financial statements are connected, and procedures for financial statements forecasting, accuracy assessments, and valuation. In particular, we discuss how data analytics can help in this process.

The results of such analyses are important for investors who use them in assessing the risk and return of investments in corporate credit and equity markets. In each of those two markets we derive a standard optimization representations both for individual investments as well as for portfolios. We link these representations to real-world applications such as platform (P2P) lending, asset management, robo-advising, and high-frequency trading.
 

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  • Know which financial statements firms report and how these inform financial markets
  • Understand how data analytics can help to assess the accuracy of accounting information
  • Understand the methods and data issues involved in forecasting financial statements and estimating equity value
  • Be able to apply large-scale forecasting and valuation techniques
  • Understand the link between risk and expected returns in financial markets
  • Understand how this is different for equity and debt markets
  • Be aware of market imperfections
  • Express investment and insurance problems as standard data learning/optimization problems
  • Be able to apply this approach to FinTech business models
Belangrijk om te weten

Course Information 

  • Pre-requisites: The students are expected to master the material offered in the Canvas pre-courses on Finance and Accounting
  • Attendance of lectures is not compulsory, but the content covered in the lectures, including the discussions during the lectures are part of the exam material.
  • Topics covered
  • Overview of workload (e.g. reading and/or assignments and/or activities each week)
  • The course is structured as follows:
    • Week 1: Financial statements
    • Week 2: Sources and accuracy of financial statements
    • Week 3: Forecasting financial statements and equity value
    • Week 4: Standard screening problems: applications in portfolio selection, insurance, liquidity provision, credit applications, and more
    • Week 5: Investing in debt and equity markets
    • Week 6: Risk preferences and profiling: applications to robo-advice

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud

The course Principles of Management will introduce you to the field of business administration and its various sub-disciplines. Business Administration is an interdisciplinary and a context-based field of study concerned with the organisation and the market environment of businesses. It is a problem-oriented discipline focusing on issues within organisations (how does an organisation set different goals and objectives?) and the interaction and relationship of the business with its surrounding (how do political factors affect the business?).

Similar to the discipline itself, this course will be context-based, using cases and examples presenting the latest business developments and current challenges business face for students to better understand the business world. Topics that will be discussed include the global context of business (business environments and business types), the business of managing, people in organisations (Human Resource Management, leadership and teams), managing information (IT), principles of marketing and finance, and political, social, economic, technological and ethical considerations affecting business. The course will provide basic knowledge on business therewith preparing you for more specialised 200 and 300 level Economics & Business major courses.

Leerdoelen After the course, students are able to:
  • Understand the main theoretical perspectives on management and how they relate to the tasks, processes and content of managerial work in organizations;
  • Understand the different elements that comprise an organization and relate these to organizational structure and organizational performance;
  • Define and critically reflect on the (international) business environment;
  • Discuss theories and applications of human resource management;
  • Describe and explain the processes, tools and content involved in managing strategy;
  • Explain how marketing can add value to the business, identify the marketing environment and its stakeholders;
  • Discuss and critically reflect on generic methods of control and performance management, including financial measures to assess performance;
  • Critically reflect on how information systems, and ERP systems in particular, can transform organizations and what the antecedents for its success are;
  • Evaluate the significance of contemporary issues in business and management.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Negotiation training requires both intellectual training and developing skills. The main assumptions of this course are: (a) negotiating is a process that can be understood and (b) negotiating is a skill that can be taught and can be learned. The core questions posed in this course are:
 
  • What are the advantages and disadvantages of various strategies?
  • What do these strategies require for success?
  • When would these strategies be most appropriate?

The course is a combination of reading & understanding theory (through the assigned book and academic articles) as well as applying the theory in simulated negotiation role-plays and a research project. The minor consists primarily of plenary lectures based on required theoretical literature. Each lecture consists of a part of discussing the theory and a part where students are applying this theory (e.g. online/offline role plays). In parallel students prepare and execute a research project (e.g. field experiment, survey-based study) where they actively apply insights from the theory while focusing on a topic of their choice.

The main contents covered in this course are:
  • The theory of negotiation, including behavioral decision making & decision analytic perspectives,
  • Conceptual frameworks to analyze conflict situations in personal and business-related settings and to design negotiation strategies to successfully resolve them.
  • Negotiation techniques and their underlying theoretical explanations.
  • Multi-party and intercultural negotiations.
  • The role of power, influence and persuasion in negotiations.
  • The role of emotions in negotiation situations.
  • Online negotiations using software agents.
  • The role of gender and personality style in negotiations
  • The role of non-verbal communications and lie detection in negotiations
  • How to manage difficult negotiations/people and the role of negotiation ethics.
Leerdoelen
The learning objectives of the course in terms of academic knowledge are:
  • Learn various negotiation theories.
  • Analyze conflict situations and design negotiation strategies to successfully resolve them.
  • Identify negotiation techniques and their underlying theoretical explanations.
  • Understand multi-party and intercultural negotiations.
  • Comprehend the role of power, influence and persuasion in negotiations
  • Identify the role of emotions in negotiation situations.
  • Gain insights on the role of gender and personality in negotiations
  • Understand non-verbal communication and detect non-verbal cues in negotiations
  • Investigate the role of negotiation ethics.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

De cursus Privaat- en ondernemingsrecht bevat een inleiding in het (privaat)recht. Er wordt aandacht besteed aan de verschillende soorten ondernemingsvormen in het eerste deel van de cursus. In het tweede deel van de cursus staat het verbintenissenrecht en het vermogensrecht centraal. De voorgaande onderworpen worden getoetst door middel van een schriftelijk tentamen.

De onderwerpen die in de cursus worden bestudeerd:

  • inleiding recht (algemene begrippen);
  • personenvennootschappen;
  • rechtspersonen (overwegend de besloten vennootschap en de naamloze vennootschap);
  • fusies en overnames;
  • bronnen van verbintenis;
  • overeenkomst en (on)rechtmatige daad als bron verbintenis;
  • niet-nakoming van verbintenissen;
  • begrippen goederenrecht en overdracht (inclusief derdenbescherming).
Leerdoelen

Als econoom zal de student bij het nemen van beslissingen oog moeten hebben voor de bestaande juridische problemen en de oplossingen hiervoor. Na het volgen en behalen van deze cursus moet de student derhalve niet alleen in staat zijn het juridische probleem te beschrijven, maar moet hij tevens de relevante rechtsregels kunnen vinden, waarmee het probleem tot een oplossing kan worden gebracht. De student wordt vertrouwd gemaakt met de belangrijkste grondslagen en begrippen op het gebied van het recht.

In het bijzonder wordt in deze cursus aandacht besteed aan het verbintenissenrecht, het vermogensrecht en het ondernemingsrecht.

Meer concreet. De student kan:

  • de basisbegrippen van het recht toepassen.
  • ten aanzien van de personenvennootschappen de noodzakelijke rechtsregels ten aanzien van oprichting, vertegenwoordiging, aansprakelijkheid en verdelingen van winsten en verliezen toepassen.
  • de voorgeschreven theorie omtrent de rechtspersonen (in het bijzonder de besloten vennootschap en naamloze vennootschap) toepassen.
  • de verschillende vormen van fusie- en overnames toepassen.
  • de bronnen van verbintenis benoemen en de samenhangende begrippen hieraan relateren.
  • beoordelen of er een rechtsgeldige overeenkomst tot stand is gekomen, wat de inhoud daarvan is en wat de gevolgen zijn als er niet aan de noodzakelijke voorwaarden is voldaan.
  • beoordelen of er sprake is van een (on)rechtmatige daad of een kwalitatieve aansprakelijkheid en deze leerstukken kunnen toepassen.
  • het leerstuk van de niet-nakoming toepassen om te beoordelen of een recht op schadevergoeding ontstaat en of ontbinding of opschorting mogelijk is.
  • de overdracht van verschillende soorten goederen (inclusief de derdenbescherming) toepassen.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Uit de evaluatie met de opleidingscommissie bleek dat studenten tevreden waren over de nieuwe aanpak met de kennisclips en het trainen met casuistiek. De studentleden wilden nog wel expliciet benadrukken dat het bestuderen van de gehele voorgeschreven literatuur van belang is voor het behalen van de cursus.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['mr. MM van Campen', 'mr. MP van Eeden - van Harskamp', 'mr. MR Hebly', 'mr. R Westrik', 'mr. ZH Duijnstee - van Imhoff', 'mr.dr. MY Schaub', 'prof.dr. KKECT Swinnen', 'prof.dr. LFH Enneking']
text:
Inhoud In dit vak wordt het Rotterdamse credo ‘where law meets business’ in de praktijk gebracht. Het vak rust inhoudelijk op de drie pijlers van het vermogensrecht: delictueel aansprakelijkheidsrecht, contractenrecht en goederen- en insolventierecht. Het vak omvat bedrijfs- en kantoorbezoeken, masterclasses, schriftelijke en mondelinge opdrachten en is geënt op problemen in de praktijk, die op een juridisch-academische wijze worden opgelost. Leerdoelen
  • argumenten uit de bestudeerde literatuur inzake het centrale onderwerp van de module onder woorden brengen en analyseren en de verschillende invalshoeken synthetiseren tot een afgewogen standpunt;
  • de huidige stand van de rechtspraak inzake het centrale onderwerp van de module onder woorden brengen en analyseren en deze toepassen op een concrete casus;
  • identificeren wat de voornaamste praktijkproblemen zijn inzake het centrale onderwerp van de module en het belang en de omvang van die problemen inschatten;
  • in samenwerking oplossingen aandragen voor een juridisch complex praktijkprobleem en kan binnen die samenwerking zich een eigen visie vormen en die motiveren.
  • met betrekking tot een complexe juridische praktijkkwestie een inhoudelijke positie schriftelijk innemen en in een mondeling debat verdedigen.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Popular accounts of privacy assert that it is a kind of commodity that may be ‘traded’ in exchange for security, or even convenience. This often overlooks how popular and even scholarly understandings of privacy are shaped by technological affordances as well as ideology. Moreover, these accounts shape what is considered appropriate and even ethical for media users, including researchers. This course considers how privacy is made meaningful as a legal/policy requirement, a cultural reference, and an ethical guide. Students will apply multidisciplinary accounts of privacy to various professional contexts, including their own scholarship.

This course aims to develop the students’ critical thinking about privacy and ethics issues of new technologies. It does so by exploring how privacy thought has evolved from being the ‘right to be let alone’ to being key for a free and democratic society, the introduction of the GDPR and the legislative focus on consent. Further to privacy, this module discusses the ethical dimension of Artificial Intelligence and ethics in research, which it will help provide the students with a solid foundation to conduct future research and work. Leerdoelen

Students have knowledge and understanding of:

  • Multi-disciplinary accounts of privacy and other related concepts.
  • How new technologies may impact public perception of social and ethical conditions.

Students have developed the skills to:

  • Critique technological advancements and applications in terms of their ethical and privacy impacts.
  • Design and implement privacy-oriented tools, such as, privacy impact assessments and research ethics considerations.
  • Differentiate between the different privacy conceptualisations and discuss their importance to the development of the concept of privacy.
  • Formulate research problems related to privacy in socio-technological systems.

course_title: Privacy, Surveillance and New Media Technologies
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Contemporary surveillance is a multi-directional, multifaceted and technologically-mediated phenomenon. Social media, mobile communications, sensor networks are already part of the surveillance activities of many public and private organizations. At the same time, privacy enhancing technologies and regulations as well as peer surveillance give people room for negotiation and action. In this course we will study and critically analyse these practices and associated technologies. This involves reflection on our relation to technologies and their role in our contemporary culture as well as on our understanding of surveillance and privacy and the way they are construed in different genres of media and in academic literature. Leerdoelen This course aims to give students a broader understanding of surveillance and privacy in our technologically mediated culture. At the end of the course students can:
  • Discuss key surveillance concepts and metaphors.
  • Understand and apply theories of privacy, surveillance, and technology to a variety of situations/contexts.
  • Identify the role of new media technologies in contemporary global surveillance practices.
  • Identify privacy issues in these practices and develop strategies for resilience and solutions to resolve them. 
Students have developed skills to:
  • Analyze contemporary practices of surveillance and of privacy protection.
  • Present arguments defending or criticizing influential conceptualizations of surveillance.
  • Integrate theoretical and practical knowledge on surveillance, privacy and new media technologies into a written paper.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
From very humble beginnings in the 1980s, Private Equity has become a very large Asset Class. Although fundraising has levelled off in 2019 and 2020 from an all-time record in 2018, still, at the end of 2020 over $2 trillion of “dry powder” globally is looking to be invested by PE funds. 

This course aims to give students a solid introduction to the world of Private Equity (including Venture Capital and Buyouts). It focuses on the following (along with practical insight from prior transactions) main areas of knowledge that underpin the PE environment: 

  • "Organizational” topics related to PE funds & investing; 
  • Cash flow analysis & modeling (we will be using a PE/LBO model for that); 
  • Review of corporate valuation methods; 
  • PE investment process (a complete cycle from a purchase idea to a completion of acquisition; and from putting the asset up for sale through to a complete exit) - we will follow a “live” (recently completed) transaction; 
  • PE transaction structuring; 
  • Negotiation of a Term Sheet/Letter of Intent and Share Purchase Agreement (SPA); 
  • Finalization of the transaction price (Locked Box and Completion Accounts mechanisms); 
  • Practical key lessons from prior transactions, i.e. practical experience; 

With the exception of item 1 (above), where some theory and “informational” delivery (deliberately kept to a modest minimum) is scheduled, this course focuses on practical aspects and transaction based learning. 


Entry requirements or required background knowledge 
As the course is based on the understanding of finance concepts developed in core courses, it requires a reasonable knowledge of accounting, corporate finance, basics of theoretical valuation as well as proficiency in Excel. It assumes students have taken appropriate pre-requisites. 

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  • Understand PE general concepts, how PE funds are formed, how they are managed and operate, how they pursue value creation for their stakeholders. 
  • Be knowledgeable about the key attributes of private equity as an asset class; be able to apply specific Private Equity valuation and modelling techniques. 
  • Understand the PE process and all components needed to successfully complete a PE transaction (valuation, leverage, transaction structure, transaction due diligence SPA signing, closing and post-closing). 
  • Understand how market conditions impact the Private Equity industry: leverage & credit markets, equity market valuations. 
  • Anticipate events and trends within the Private Equity industry and gain deeper insight of advanced corporate finance.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

Continuous random variables, continuous distributions, moment generating functions, discrete and continuous joint distributions, independence , conditional distributions, conditional expectations, variance, covariance, functions of random variables, transformation methods, Central Limit Theorem, stochastic convergence, sampling distributions.

This course use knowledge from FEB21018X Introduction to Statistics and FEB21021X Analysis, and is required for FEB21007X Statistics, FEB22008X Markov Processes and FEB22004X Econometrics 1.

Leerdoelen
  • Understand the basics of probability theory, including central concepts and proofs of central results.
  • Obtain knowledge of and proficiency in reasoning and calculating with probabilities: continuous and discrete random variables, functions of random variables, transformation methods, joint and conditional distributions.
  • Obtain insight and experience in the use of probability theory in statistics: sampling distributions, central limit theorem.
  • Gets insight into basic results in probability theory that are important in econometrics.
  • Gets experience in applying mathematical concepts and techniques of probability theory.
Extra It is not allowed to use a programmable calculator during the (re-)examination.

course_title: Production Cultures in the Streaming Industries
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This is an exciting and transformative moment for streaming industries across the globe. As the economics of media industries shift from advertising-based revenue models to subscriber-based revenue models, streaming platforms that provide different types of content directly to consumers are becoming increasingly important. For example, the global expansion of streaming video on-demand services like Netflix both reflect and drive change within traditional audiovisual media industries like television and film. Yet, the proprietary nature of streaming audience data and the near total lack of data transparency offered by streaming companies themselves (e.g. Netflix, Spotify, YouTube) creates a variety of challenges for media industry researchers. 
  Leerdoelen The main goal of this research workshop is to train students to overcome these challenges using the “production culture” approach. This approach, sometimes called media historiography, media industry studies, or trade press analysis, is grounded in the academic perspective that understands media industry discourse as centrally important to understanding media industry practice.
 
Students will learn how to gather and analyze relevant data about the streaming industries from a variety of publicly available secondary sources including but not limited to trade press articles, press releases, trade and popular press interviews, videos of industry events, annual reports, policy reports, and financial documents. Students will formulate a research question related to a specific streaming service situated within a broader streaming industry. Students will create a qualitative research design, collect and then analyze data. Their efforts culminate in an academic research paper.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Course overview 

As the world turns, many (workplace) innovations result in speedy changes to both our personal and professional lives that outpace an individual’s ability to adapt. To stay connected and up-to-date, the future of work calls for lifelong learning (‘LLL’) and emphasises continued development of cognitive, social, emotional, and technological skills. It no longer is enough to simply obtain a Bachelor degree. Those who want to remain employable and successful throughout their careers and want to fully participate in society need to embrace a growth mindset and muster the (self-)awareness, discipline, and motivation to constantly develop themselves and others.  

In addition, our increasingly globalised world leads to higher levels of ambiguity and complexity. Many of the problems and challenges managers are confronted with today (and in the future) require careful consideration and evaluation of different trade-offs and stakeholders. Those who want to become agents for positive change need to understand how to navigate these complexities with integrity, open-mindedness, and balance. 

Clearly, it should now be evident to you as future (business/management) professional that it is not enough anymore to solely be a content expert and understand the intricacies of subjects such as finance, marketing, and operations management. Instead, you need to be equally skilful when it comes to things such as time- and self-management, emotion regulation, stakeholder management and moral decision-making. 

This course (Professional Development & Mentoring 1) aims to support you in developing these skills. This requires continuous self-reflection, feedback and above all practice. Therefore, particular emphasis is placed on small-scale workshops in which you and your fellow students will actively practice the skills taught through lectures, online modules, and self-study. Throughout the course, you will regularly reflect on your own development and receive (peer) feedback. 

Leerdoelen

Learning goals 

After following this course, students are able to: 

  • Demonstrate, self-regulate, and reflect upon (their own) professional student behaviour (e.g., schedule personal time; track personal development; take personal accountability).   

  • Demonstrate collaborative and successful teamwork behaviour in diverse and inclusive team settings (e.g., active listening; perspective-taking; constructive feedback giving and receiving; team accountability).    

  • Demonstrate basic coaching skills. 

  • Display a growth mindset full of curiosity, self-awareness, balance, and open-mindedness.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. MA de Bree', 'dr. TA Alade', 'JAJ Batenburg - Suijker']
text:
Inhoud Course overview
The world is demanding new leadership for an ever more complex and dynamic world. Professional Development is a course organized by the department of Business-Society Management and focuses on the role of the business leader. The goal of the course is to offer students information, tools and skills to better understand, engage in and change the self, the other person, the organization and the world. 

Professional Development should not only include tools for understanding and influencing the environment, but also exploring and questioning the students’ own frames of reference. Professional Development is based on the principles of transformational learning which means that the course is both outside in and inside out. This makes Professional Development a rather provocative course, with much time spend on self-exploration, living up to RSM’s mission to be a force for positive change by addressing the role of business and business leaders in both locally and globally relevant problems. The course points at the responsibility of the business leader to understand her or his own frames of reference as a foundation for contributing to positive change in the world.
Students are required to formulate personal learning goals right at the start of the course, which will later on serve as a point of reference for the personal essay. Leerdoelen Learning goals

After following this course, the student is able to:
  • Monitor the realization of several more personal learning goals by critically incorporating the results of self-reflection, peer- and tutor feedback.
  • Master presentation, writing, coaching and negotiation skills to a level that allows the student to adapt application of the skills to variation in intrinsic (personal) and extrinsic (environmental) factors in a practical context.
  • Critically review and transform his or her personal frame of reference.
  • Explain new insights to change and apply these in their own personal, professional, and/or educational environment.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Professional Development and Consulting runs from September till December and forms the foundation in which students connect core course knowledge to skills development, personal development, and a real-life organisational context.

The main objective of this course is to help students be aware of their competencies and further develop these. Competencies consists of knowledge, skills, and attitude and therefore within this course students will gain new skills, work on their professional development, and connect the knowledge they acquired in our four knowledge courses (Strategic HRM, Organisational Design, People Analytics and Leading Organisational Change) to a real-life organisational context.

More specifically, this course consists of three elements:
  • Company Project. In teams, our students will step in the role of consultant and apply newly learned competencies a real-life organisation. The objective is that the student consultants will develop new and interesting insights and advice for a great variety of companies.
  • Skills Workshops. We prepare students to enter a knowledge course by training them on skills needed in that specific course. Students will follow workshops to develop these skills (e.g. leadership, collaboration, visualization and decision making).
  • Portfolio. In tandem with the project and workshops, our students will work on their portfolio. Based on self-assessment and feedback received by peers and professors, we encourage students to regularly reflect. Students will engage in mentoring circles (3 peers and an alum) aimed at students supporting each other and grow together. In doing so, students will be able to critically evaluate their own strengths and weaknesses and develop further.
Leerdoelen

Learning Objectives

Apply relevant skills in the field of People, Organisations and Change to a real-life organisational context. Success criteria:
  • Actively participate in the workshops about collaboration / evaluating a paper / providing peer feedback / collect data and assess its validity / entering an organisation / presenting + creating a company presentation / visualisations / meta reflection / group decision making / leading vs. following / finding your core values
  • Apply the above defined skills during the company project and the core courses and collect feedback on you displaying the defined skills
  • Reflect on applying these skills in your final reflection

Lead a consulting project based on the phases of consulting. Success criteria:
  • Know the phases of consulting and define the scope of your project
  • Develop an understanding of the current situation and challenges in an organisation (entering an organisation, exploring the problem, expectation management, setting the scene)
  • Manage unexpected issues that arise during your project (communicate early and clearly, involve relevant stakeholders, be in charge)Actively manage expectations within your team, with your client and with stakeholders in our MSc programme
  • Lead the project by combining a helicopter view with detailed information
Integrate self-awareness and the impact you have on others to develop your professional identity. Success criteria:
  • Take ownership of the creation of your portfolio by actively and frequently reflecting on your development and make sure you take charge of deadlines, input, quality of work et cetera.
  • Develop a better understanding of your strengths and weaknesses as a POC-professional based on the feedback you received from peers and lecturers / filling in the surveys and questionnaires about personal development
  • Understand the implications and possibilities of your strengths and weaknesses by discussing these in your mentoring circles and reflecting on these in your portfolio.
  • Provide and receive (peer) feedback regularly and take ownership on implementation of change.
  • Create a safe environment for yourself and others to share and engage in mentoring circles 
  • Demonstrate stakeholder management skills through communication with peers, inviting the client and your lecturers to give you feedback and by actively sharing your story with others.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud The module Professional Development focuses on the preparation for the labor market. The program is composed of:
  • a four-days study-trip to International Organizations and Non-Governmental Organizations in Geneva. The study-trip is mandatory and involves extra costs [airfare ticket, lodging];
  • a one day visit to the European institutions in Brussels
  • a series of guest-lectures by practitioners and labor market experts to make students familiar with the and to help them to find their way at the international labor market.
The trip to Geneva takes place in the Fall, the visit to Brussels in the Spring. Students are kindly invited to participate in the design and organization of the program. Leerdoelen After passing the module professional development students will be able to:

* understand the range of possible careers available to the graduates, including their advantages and disadvantages
* describe the main features of the international labor market, including selection procedures and entrance requirements of relevant employers;
* make informed choices about possible career paths;
* prepare an application package that meet international standards in order to be successful on the international labor market.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['A Mamede Soares Braga, MSc', 'B Kemmere', 'dr. I Merkelbach', 'dr. M Dewies', 'dr. PL Kocken', 'dr. T Magnee', 'MHL Hollaar, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

In this course, students will have the opportunity to acquire skills necessary for employment in the professional practice of interventions and policies aimed at health behavior change. They will learn skills in evaluating their own achievement in critically reflecting on personal and professional development in the context of health psychology and behavior change. After the course students have the skills to carry out the steps of planning behavior change programs and reflect on their personal and team skills to manage such programs. The course runs in combination with the course Health Psychology and Behavior change and students will have the chance to develop skills they can apply when developing the behavior change intervention in that course.

The professional skills course addresses four topics:

  • Team skills: with whom do you collaborate and how?
  • Managing the process of project planning: how do you organize your project and use time management or budgeting?
  • Inclusiveness in health policy and interventions.
  • Diffusion, implementation and communication: knowledge brokerage aimed at your target population such as policy makers.
Leerdoelen
At the end of this course you will be able to...

• Critically assess personal strengths and weaknesses with regard to personal skills and team skills.
• Apply the skills and methods for planning health behaviour change programs.
• Create a personal portfolio using a personal leadership plan on where you are, a reflection on strengths and weaknesses, a plan with your personal and professional goals, and skills you need to develop.
